=== Criticisms and responses ===
Critics assert that juvenile life insurance is unnecessary due to the low likelihood of child mortality and that the insurance premiums should be used for other purposes. Proponents of juvenile life insurance argue that a well-structured policy minimizes the initial death benefit and maximizes cash value growth to provide a savings vehicle with a lifetime of benefit.
Critics also claim that investing in [[stocks]], [[bond (finance)|bonds]] or [[mutual funds]] can provide higher [[return (finance)|returns]] with lower [[fees]] than a comparable juvenile life insurance policy. Although juvenile life insurance is not an [[investment]] product, proponents point to many juvenile life insurance products where cash value is 100% linked to equity indexes. This allows a policy owner to participate in stock market growth and do this in a tax advantaged environment. In addition, some of these products offer a growth floor, meaning the cash value of a juvenile life insurance product will never decrease.
Some question the fees associated with life insurance products. They note that approximately half of the first year premium and an ongoing percentage of future premiums are paid as [[commission (remuneration)|commissions]] to the insurance agent. Juvenile life insurance advocates note that over the long term, management fees for other financial products typically will exceed juvenile life insurance policy commissions. For example in the illustration above, typical management fees of 1% annually would exceed, in every year following the 6th year, the $900–$1,800 one-time commission payment paid to the insurance agent.
=== Choosing a company ===
Life insurance is a promise between the policy owner and the insurance company. A life insurance policy is expected to perform many years into the future; therefore the long-term financial viability of a firm is important when selecting an insurance company. The credit rating of an insurance company can be used to determine the financial health of an insurance company. [[Moody’s]], [[A.M. Best Company]], [[Fitch Ratings|Fitch]], and [[Standard and Poor’s]] provide such ratings.
== Taxation ==
=== Taxation of cash value === The cash value of a juvenile life insurance policy can be borrowed or withdrawn at any time. Borrowing using the policy as the sole collateral is typically not a taxable event, although interest must be paid or accrued. A withdrawal up to the cumulative premium (also known as basis) paid into a policy is not subject to taxation. Withdrawals over the cumulative premium are taxable in the year that the money is withdrawn.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.axa-equitable.com/life-insurance/plan/tax-free-withdrawals.html|title=Are withdrawals from a cash value life insurance policy ever tax free?|website=www.axa-equitable.com}}</ref><ref>http://juvenilelifeinsurance.org/faq.html</ref> If money is intended to be withdrawn, the policy is often transferred to the juvenile, who generally is in a lower income tax bracket than the policy owner.
=== Taxation of death benefit === Death proceeds of a juvenile life insurance policy are received by a beneficiary of the insured free of income tax. Proceeds are included in the estate of the deceased and may be subject to estate tax if the policy is not owned by a trust.
== Use of trusts ==
Trusts are used extensively in conjunction with many forms of life insurance. A trust, such as a Crummey trust, allows for the cash value of a juvenile life insurance policy to be withdrawn and used without incurring federal or state income tax. For example, a Crummey trust for the purpose of paying for college and providing lifetime benefits could function as follows:
* Parents create a Crummey trust for the purpose of providing for a child’s health, education, maintenance or support. * Parent A writes an annual check under the gift tax exclusion amount to the Trust for the insurance premium due. Parent B is the trustee authorized to administer the trust assets. The beneficiary must be given a chance to claim the gift of the premium. However, since the beneficiary is a minor, Parent B has 30 days to ‘claim’ the funds (on behalf of their child). Parent B signs a release to state that the funds will not be claimed and after 30 days the funds pass to the trust without any further action by either the parent or beneficiary. * Trust receives annually a check from Parent A and pays the annual premium due. * When the minor incurs educational costs, parent B, as the trustee, withdraws money from the cash value of the juvenile insurance policy to pay tuition, room and board, and other permitted costs. Later, funds may be used for ongoing education, maintenance and support. *Policy remains in force for the life of the child.
In this scenario, neither the child nor the parent ever have “control” or “ownership” of the policy and therefore distributions are excluded from any gift tax or estate tax and will be received at the insured’s income tax rate. The cash value of the juvenile life insurance policy is generally not included in a financial-aid assessment since the policy is owned by the trust, and is not considered as an asset of either the parents or the insured.{{Citation needed|reason=A child's trust interest would generally be reported as an asset on financial-aid assessments.|date=May 2017}}

Stock |location=London |page=186}} | patronage = Ledbury, Herefordshire, England| issues=|suppressed_date=|tradition=|influenced=|major_works=|honorific_prefix=|honorific_suffix=|birth_name=}}'''Katherine of Ledbury''' (also known as '''Katherine de Audley''' or '''St. Katherine of Ledbury'''; born 1272) was a [[Gloucestershire]]-born noblewoman of the 13th century who became an [[anchorite|anchoress]] in [[Ledbury|Ledbury, Herefordshire]]. Katherine was the subject of [[William Wordsworth|William Wordsworth’s]] [[sonnet]], “St. Catherine of Ledbury,” and is remembered as a [[patron saint]] of that town.{{cite book |last1=Clay |first1=Rotha Mary |title=The Hermits and Anchorites of England |date=1914 |publisher=Methuen |location=London |page=74-75}} She has often been confused with the 4th century [[martyr]] [[Catherine of Alexandria]], whose cult in Ledbury preexisted hers.{{cite web |title=A woman Ledbury will never forget |url=https://www.worcesternews.co.uk/news/7726572.A_woman_Ledbury_will_never_forget/ |website=Worcester News |publisher=Newsquest |accessdate=1 December 2018}} == Life == Katherine was born in 1272 in [[Brimpsfield|Brimpsfield, Gloucestershire]], to [[John Giffard, 1st Baron Giffard]], the owner of [[Brimpsfield Castle]]. She married the [[Baron Audley|Baron Nicholas de Audley]], had two sons and a daughter, and lived at [[Hellens|Hellens Manor]] in [[Much Marcle]].{{cite journal |last1=McAvoy |first1=Liz Herbert |title=Uncovering the ‘saintly Anchoress’: myths of Medieval anchoritism and the reclusion of Katharine de Audley |journal=Women's History Review |date=2013 |volume=22 |issue=5 |page=801-819 |url=https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/09612025.2013.769380 |accessdate=1 December 2018}} After her husband died in 1299, she became an anchoress in Ledbury.{{cite book |last1=Clay |first1=Rotha Mary |title=The Hermits and Anchorites of England |date=1914 |publisher=Methuen |location=London |page=74-75}} Various sources suggest she originally went missing on 25 February 1308, the day of [[Edward II of England|King Edward II's]] coronation, before finally appearing in Ledbury as a [[recluse]].{{cite book |last1=Lever |first1=Michael |title=Ledbury Through Time |date=2013 |publisher=Amberley Publishing Limited |location=Stroud, Gloucestershire |isbn=9781445615257}}{{cite web |last1=Lever |first1=Michael |title=Mabel's Furlong |url=http://www.ledburyhistorysociety.co.uk/ledburyhistory/ledburysnippets/files/709fb167d6138170ab8bb122b07c9846-57.html |website=Ledbury History Society |publisher=Michael Lever |accessdate=2 December 2018}} The scholar Liz Hebert McAvoy has speculated that Katherine's disappearance and reappearance in Ledbury may have been an attempt to avoid being married to another lord after the death of her husband, which McAvoy claimed was common practice at that time.{{cite journal |last1=McAvoy |first1=Liz Herbert |title=Uncovering the ‘saintly Anchoress’: myths of Medieval anchoritism and the reclusion of Katharine de Audley |journal=Women's History Review |date=2013 |volume=22 |issue=5 |url=https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/09612025.2013.769380 |accessdate=2 December 2018}} According to the [[antiquarian]] Rotha Mary Clay, Katherine gave away part of her maternal inheritance in 1312, and based on the location and signatory of the deed, it is likely she was already living in Ledbury and that the bishop had enclosed her as an anchoress in the church of St. Michael and All Angels.{{cite book |last1=Clay |first1=Rotha Mary |title=The Hermits and Anchorites of England |date=1914 |publisher=Methuen |location=London |page=75}} In 1323, Katherine was receiving £30 a year through the sheriff of Ledbury, “the sums being paid,” according to Clay, “out of lands which were in the custody of her husband’s executor.”{{cite book |last1=Clay |first1=Rotha Mary |title=The Hermits and Anchorites of England |date=1914 |publisher=Methuen |location=London |page=74-75}} Clay concluded that Katherine had made arrangements about her property in order to obtain a pension that would fund her life as an anchoress.{{cite book |last1=Clay |first1=Rotha Mary |title=The Hermits and Anchorites of England |date=1914 |publisher=Methuen |location=London |page=74-75}} == Veneration == === Legends === [[File:Sketch by Jabez Allies of animal markings found in sandstone in Whelpley Brook (1835).png|thumb|Jabez Allies' 1835 sketch of animal markings found in Whelpley Brook, which legend attributed to Katherine's stolen mare and colt.{{cite book |last1=Allies |first1=Jabez |title=Observations on Certain Curious Indentations in the Old Red Sand-Stone of Worcestershire and Herefordshire Considered as the Tracks of Antedeluvian Animals |date=1835 |publisher=William Edwards |location=London |page=1}}]] Legends have attributed clairvoyance and a miraculous power of prayer to Katherine.{{cite web |title="CATHERINE, SAINT," in Encyclopaedia Britannica, 11th Edition, Volume 5, Slice 5, "Cat" to "Celt" |url=http://www.gutenberg.org/files/33239/33239-h/33239-h.htm |website=Project Gutenberg |publisher=Project Gutenberg |accessdate=1 December 2018}}{{cite book |last1=Clay |first1=Rotha Mary |title=The Hermits and Anchorites of England |date=1914 |publisher=Methuen |location=London |page=74-75}}{{cite book |last1=Allies |first1=Jabez |title=Observations on Certain Curious Indentations in the Old Red Sand-Stone of Worcestershire and Herefordshire Considered as the Tracks of Antedeluvian Animals |date=1835 |publisher=William Edwards |location=London |page=1}}{{cite web |title=A woman Ledbury will never forget |url=https://www.worcesternews.co.uk/news/7726572.A_woman_Ledbury_will_never_forget/ |website=Worcester News |publisher=Newsquest |accessdate=1 December 2018}} One Ledbury legend has it that Katherine chose to come to Ledbury because a vision had shown her she must not rest until she arrived at a place where the church bells rang unaided. According to Rotha Mary Clay, the legend narrates that Katherine and her maid Mabel “wandered from place to place, following out of [[Worcestershire]] into [[Herefordshire]] the hoof-marks of [Katherine's] mare which had been stolen.”{{cite book |last1=Clay |first1=Rotha Mary |title=The Hermits and Anchorites of England |date=1914 |publisher=Methuen |location=London |page=74-75}} The antiquarian [[Jabez Allies]] recounted that, in the version of the legend he'd heard, Katherine had prayed in response to the theft, and both the thief's footprints and the horse's hoof-prints had become "deeply indented, not only in the earth, but also in the stones wherever they trod."{{cite book |last1=Allies |first1=Jabez |title=Observations on Certain Curious Indentations in the Old Red Sand-Stone of Worcestershire and Herefordshire Considered as the Tracks of Antedeluvian Animals |date=1835 |publisher=William Edwards |location=London |page=3}} The antiquarian later drew a sketch of the supposed marks, which he claimed to have found in the sandstone rocks of Whelpley Brook in Herefordshire and which the locals called the "tracks of St. Catherine's Mare and Colt."{{cite book |last1=Allies |first1=Jabez |title=Observations on Certain Curious Indentations in the Old Red Sand-Stone of Worcestershire and Herefordshire Considered as the Tracks of Antedeluvian Animals |date=1835 |publisher=William Edwards |location=London |page=1}} He later claimed that local people also said the marks in the stones were a "representation of the loaves which Saint Catherine used to give to the poor."{{cite book |last1=Allies |first1=Jabez |title=Observations on Certain Curious Indentations in the Old Red Sand-Stone of Worcestershire and Herefordshire Considered as the Tracks of Antedeluvian Animals |date=1835 |publisher=William Edwards |location=London |page=10}} The stones themselves were for many years used by local people as charms or safeguards against robbery, and according to the [[Saturday Review (London newspaper)|Saturday Review]], people continued to believe the story of Katherine and her mare into the early 19th century.{{cite book |title="The Origin of Local Tradition," in The Saturday Review, vol. 46 |date=November 16, 1878 |publisher=John W. Parker and Son |location=London |page=619 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BAxjOcOaaTQC&pg=RA1-PA619#v=onepage&q&f=false |accessdate=2 December 2018}} Having continued her journey and reached the village of [[Bosbury]], Katherine heard the bells ringing and sent Mabel to identify the cause. She said she knew "she was to end her days at some place whose name terminated with bury."{{cite book |last1=Allies |first1=Jabez |title=Observations on Certain Curious Indentations in the Old Red Sand-Stone of Worcestershire and Herefordshire Considered as the Tracks of Antedeluvian Animals |date=1835 |publisher=William Edwards |location=London |page=1}} When Mabel returned and said the bells were being rung for a wedding, Katherine said this was not the place, and they continued on their journey.{{cite book |last1=Allies |first1=Jabez |title=Observations on Certain Curious Indentations in the Old Red Sand-Stone of Worcestershire and Herefordshire Considered as the Tracks of Antedeluvian Animals |date=1835 |publisher=William Edwards |location=London |page=7}} It was only upon reaching Ledbury that Katherine finally heard the church bells ringing of their own accord and decided to remain “under the shadow of the bell-tower” as an anchoress.{{cite book |last1=Clay |first1=Rotha Mary |title=The Hermits and Anchorites of England |date=1914 |publisher=Methuen |location=London |page=74-75}} After building a hermitage at the church, she was said to have lived on herbs and milk.{{cite book |last1=Parr |first1=Frank |title="Katherine Audley, of Ledbury," in The Antiquary, vol. 3 |date=1881 |publisher=E. Stock |location=London |page=186}} Another legend, repeated in the [[Worcester News]], suggests that the fortunes of the town of Ledbury are linked to a prophecy of Katherine's:
Legend has it that, before her death, [Katherine] declared that the door to the [St. Katherine] chapel should never be opened by human hands, but should always be allowed to open by itself. If this direction had been followed, Ledbury would have become "the richest town in England." But drunken revellers disobeyed her instructions, and the town had to make do with a more modest, though not an unprosperous future.{{cite web |title=A woman Ledbury will never forget |url=https://www.worcesternews.co.uk/news/7726572.A_woman_Ledbury_will_never_forget/ |website=Worcester News |publisher=Newsquest |accessdate=1 December 2018}}
=== Cult === The Chapter House of St. Michael and All Angels Church in Ledbury may have been built as a shrine to Katherine.{{cite web |title=History of Church |url=http://www.ledburyparishchurch.org.uk/history.html |website=Ledbury Parish Church, St. Michael and All Angels |publisher=St Michael & All Angels Ledbury |accessdate=1 December 2018}} The [[Encyclopædia Britannica Eleventh Edition]] mentioned the following feast day of a "St Catherine Audley": "In Celtic and English martyrologies (November 25) there is also commemorated St Catherine Audley (c. 1400), a recluse of Ledbury, Hereford, who was reputed for piety and clairvoyance."{{cite web |title="CATHERINE, SAINT," in Encyclopaedia Britannica, 11th Edition, Volume 5, Slice 5, "Cat" to "Celt" |url=http://www.gutenberg.org/files/33239/33239-h/33239-h.htm |website=Project Gutenberg |publisher=Project Gutenberg |accessdate=1 December 2018}} Rotha Mary Clay has suggested that Katherine's sainthood came about as a result of confusion between her identity and that of Catherine of Alexandria, for whom a chapel, hospital, and almshouse in the town were named many years before Katherine de Audley was born.{{cite book |last1=Clay |first1=Rotha Mary |title=The Hermits and Anchorites of England |date=1914 |publisher=Methuen |location=London |page=74-75}} == Wordsworth's sonnet == In 1835, Wordsworth wrote the sonnet “St. Catherine of Ledbury” after taking a trip to Ledbury from [[Brinsop Court]] in Herefordshire, 20 miles away, where he was staying with his family.{{cite web |title=A woman Ledbury will never forget |url=https://www.worcesternews.co.uk/news/7726572.A_woman_Ledbury_will_never_forget/ |website=Worcester News |publisher=Newsquest |accessdate=1 December 2018}} The poem immortalized the legend of Katherine and the bells:
ST. CATHERINE OF LEDBURY When human touch (as monkish books attest) Nor was applied nor could be, Ledbury bells Broke forth in concert flung adown the dells, And upward, high as Malvern's cloudy crest; Sweet tones, and caught by a noble lady blest To rapture! Mabel listened at the side Of her loved mistress; soon the music died. And Catherine said, Here I set up my rest. Warned in a dream, the wanderer long had sought A home that by such miracle of sound Must be revealed: she heard it now, or felt The deep, deep joy of a confiding thought; And there, a saintly anchoress, she dwelt Till she exchanged for heaven that happy ground.{{cite web |last1=Wordsworth |first1=William |title=St. Catherine of Ledbury |url=https://www.bartleby.com/270/1/222.html |website=Bartleby |accessdate=1 December 2018}}

{{Infobox person | name = Lawrence Shove | birth_name = Lawrence Clive Shove | nationality = British | birth_date = 5 November 1923<ref>England & Wales, Civil Registration Death Index, 1916-2007</ref> | birth_place = British India | death_date = {{dda|1995|4|2|1923|11|5|df=y}} | death_place = [[Dunsford]], Exeter, England | occupation = [[Sound recordist]]; Theatre manager | years_active = 1960s-1980s }} {{Listen | filename = Eurasian Bittern (Botaurus stellaris) (W BOTAURUS STELLARIS R1 C1).ogg | title = Eurasian Bittern | description = Shove's 1966 recording of a booming [[Eurasian Bittern|Bittern]] (with other birdsong in the foreground) }}
'''Lawrence Clive Shove''' (5 November 1923 – 2 April 1995) was a British [[sound recordist]], specialising in field recordings of wildlife.
The "Shove collection of British wildlife" at the [[National Sound Archive]] (NSA), part of the [[British Library]] comprises 243 reels of his recordings, on [[magnetic tape]].<ref name="NSA-1">{{cite journal|date=August 1997|title=Acquisitions 1995-6|journal=Wildlife Section Newsletter|publisher=tional Sound Archive/ British Library|issue=1|page=2|url=http://www.bl.uk/reshelp/findhelprestype/sound/wildsounds/newsletter/wildnews1.pdf}}</ref> In 1969, Shove was one of the first contributors to the NSA's wildlife collection, and their wildlife recording number 00001 is his 1966 recording of a [[Eurasian bittern]] at [[Hickling Broad]], in Norfolk.<ref name="NSA-1" /> The NSA acquired his complete collection of wildlife recordings in the mid-1990s.<ref name="NSA-1" />
In 1968, he was described by the BBC as "the only full-time freelance recordist of wildlife sounds in Britain".<ref name="LOOK">{{cite news|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/626158a655d74db78369e0ada84532e1|title=LOOK|date=23 May 1968|work=[[BBC Online]]|page=19|accessdate=4 November 2015}}</ref> He was the subject of a BBC television ''[[The World About Us]]'' episode, screened on 9 April 1972,<ref name="TWAU">{{cite news|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/48d8dbbf678b49d892a3dfaf7f5f5ec8|title=The World About Us|date=6 April 1972|work=[[Radio Times]]|page=23|accessdate=4 November 2015}}</ref> and appeared on several other BBC television and radio programmes in the late 1960s and early 1970s.<ref name="Genome">{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/search/0/20?adv=0&q="Lawrence+Shove"&media=all&yf=1923&yt=2009&mf=1&mt=12&tf=00%3A00&tt=00%3A00#search|title=Search Results - Lawrence Shove|work=[[BBC Genome Project]]|accessdate=4 November 2015}}</ref>
In the 1970s and 1980s, he was manager of the [[Minack Theatre]], [[Porthcurno]], Cornwall.
The NSA have put most of Shove's recordings online, and as of November 2013 will extend access as part of a [[Europeana]] project.<ref name="Tipp">{{cite web|url=http://britishlibrary.typepad.co.uk/sound-and-vision/2013/11/europeana-creative-the-wildlife-recordings-of-lawrence-shove.html|title=Europeana Creative: the wildlife recordings of Lawrence Shove|last=Tipp|first=Cheryl|date=2013-11-01|work=Sound and vision blog|publisher=National Sound Archive/ British Library|accessdate=1 November 2013}}</ref>
== Discography ==
* ''The Country Sings'' (1963)
A series of 7", [[LP record|33⅓ rpm]], [[Extended play|EP]]s of Shove's wildlife recordings, with his narration, were published by [[Discourses (record label)|Discourses]] as part of the "Shell Nature" series, in conjunction with [[Royal Dutch Shell|Shell-Mex and BP Ltd]]. Featuring liner notes by [[Jeffery Boswall]], these included:<ref name="Tipp" /><ref>Sleeve notes</ref>
* ''Sea Birds'' (DCL 701, 1966; re-released in 1967 in different packaging) * ''Garden And Park Birds'' (DCL 702, 1966) * ''Woodland Birds'' (DCL 703, 1966) * ''Estuary Birds'' (DCL 704, 1967) * ''Field And Open Countryside Birds'' (DCL 705, 1967) * ''Moor And Heath Birds'' (DCL 706, 1967) * ''Marsh And Riverside Birds'' (DCL 707, 1967) * ''Nightingale and Dawn Chorus'' (DCL 708, 1969) * ''Mountain And Highland Birds'' (DCL 709, 1969)

page.title: List of Britain's Got Talent finalists (series 10)

revision.text:
The [[Britain's Got Talent (series 10)|tenth series]] of ''[[Britain's Got Talent]]'' started on 9 April 2016 and ended on 28 May 2016. The finalists are given in the order in which they finished.
== Richard Jones == {{main article|Richard Jones (magician)}} '''Richard Jones''' is a magician from London. He was the overall winner of the competition.
At the time of his BGT appearance, he was a soldier serving in the Cavalry band.
== Wayne Woodward == '''Wayne Woodward''' (born 1 April 1995) is an English [[swing music|swing]] [[singer]]. He was the runner up on the [[Britain's Got Talent (series 10)|tenth series]] of ''[[Britain's Got Talent]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.itv.com/britainsgottalent/live-shows/is-your-britains-got-talent-2016-winner|title=Britain's Got Talent 2016|date=28 May 2016|publisher=[[ITV (TV network)|ITV]]|accessdate=29 May 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-36407118 |title=Britain's Got Talent final |work=BBC News |publisher=BBC |date=28 May 2016 |accessdate=29 May 2016}}</ref> Woodward attended [[Kingston College (England)|Kingston College]] and he has worked as a builder.<ref name=guardian>[http://www.suttonguardian.co.uk/news/14512374.Britain_s_Got_Talent__Wayne_Woodward_makes_it_through_to_Saturday_s_final/ Wayne Woodward at Sutton Guardian]. Retrieved 29 May 2016</ref> He sang a rendition of "[[The Way You Look Tonight]]" at the audition, "[[That's Life (song)|That’s Life]]" in the semi final and "[[Feeling Good]]" in the final. Following his appearances on the show he is going into a [[recording studio]] to work on an album.<ref name=guardian2>[http://www.yourlocalguardian.co.uk/news/14530214.BGT_runner_up_Wayne_Woodward_still_eyeing_success/ Wayne Woodward Still Eyeing Success at Sutton Guardian]. Retrieved 2 June 2016</ref>
== Boogie Storm == '''Boogie Storm''' are a dancing [[Stormtrooper (Star Wars)|stormtrooper]] act. They were Simon Cowell's golden buzzer act.
== Jasmine Elcock == '''Jasmine Elcock''' (born 1 February 2002) is a singer from Essex. She was Ant & Dec's golden buzzer act. She previously took part in a stage production of "Annie".
== Beau Dermott == {{main|Beau Dermott (singer)}} '''Beau Dermott''' is a musical theatre singer. Beau lives in Widnes, Cheshire with her parents. She attends The Hammond, theatre school in Chester.
Beau rose to fame on ''Britain's Got Talent''. She was Amanda Holden's golden buzzer act. Her cousin Jack Higgins also took part in this series.
Beau has signed with Decca Records and her first album, ''[[Brave (Beau Dermott album)|Brave]]'', was released on 1 September 2017.
== Craig Ball == '''Craig Ball''' (both 11 September 1991)<ref>https://twitter.com/C2raiG</ref> is a singing impressionist, sang his edition of "Wrecking Ball" in both auditions and finals and his version of [[Adele]]'s "Hello" in the semi-final. He's currently working on singing impressions via YouTube.
== Trip Hazard == '''Trip Hazard''' is a dancing dog act along with his owner Lucy.
== 100 Voices of Gospel == '''100 Voices of Gospel''' are a gospel choir. They were Alesha Dixon's golden buzzer.
== Alex Magala == {{main article|Alex Magala}} '''Alex Magala''' is a sword swallower from Moldova.
== Balance Unity == '''Balance Unity''', real name Taylor Goodridge, is a dancer from London.
== Shannon & Peter == '''Shannon & Peter''' are a husband & wife dance duo. They were the judges wildcard.
== Mel & Jamie == '''Mel & Jamie''' are a mother & son singing duo.

{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2012}} {{Infobox scientist |name = Merle Sande |image = |image_size =150px |caption = Merle Sande |birth_date = {{birth date|1939|9|2}} |birth_place = |death_date = {{death date and age|2007|11|14|1939|9|2}} |death_place = [[Seattle, WA]] |residence = |citizenship = |nationality = American |ethnicity = |field = medicine |work_institutions = |alma_mater = [[Washington State University]]
[[University of Washington]] |doctoral_advisor = |doctoral_students = |known_for = [[infectious diseases]] |author_abbrev_bot = |author_abbrev_zoo = |influences = |influenced = |prizes = |religion = |footnotes = |signature = }} '''Merle Sande'''(September 2, 1939 – November 4, 2007) was a leading American infectious-diseases expert whose early recognition of the looming public health crisis posed by [[HIV|AIDS]] led to the development of basic protocols for how to handle infected patients. He graduated from [[Washington State University]] and received his MD degree from the [[University of Washington]], School of Medicine in Seattle. Sande was a professor of Internal Medicine from 1971–1980 at the [[University of Virginia]], where he performed research in mice on bacterial [[meningitis]] therapies such as novel antibiotics and corticosteroids. Dr Sande was Chief of Medical Services at [[San Francisco General Hospital]] in 1981 when he recognized a pattern of gay men being admitted with the rare [[pneumocystis]] pneumonia. His efforts on behalf of these patients resulted in the formation of an AIDS ward at [[San Francisco General Hospital]] and later an AIDS outpatient clinic. Teaming with such experts as [[Julie Gerberding]] and [[Paul Volberding]] he helped to craft what became known as the ''San Francisco model'' of AIDS therapy, a comprehensive, rational approach to care that avoided the fear and paranoia surrounding the disease at that time. The model addressed a need for infection-control guidelines, clinical studies and research financing and became a template for AIDS centers nationwide. Sande helped found to the Gladstone Institute of Virology and Immunology, which performed trials on some of the first anti-retrovirals such as [[zidovudine]]. He also helped to found the [[Infectious Diseases Institute]] at the [[Makerere University]] College of Health Sciences in [[Kampala]], Uganda a major center for HIV education and research in Africa. Sande was a professor of Medicine at [[University of California, San Francisco]] from 1980–1996, chairman of the department internal medicine at [[University of Utah]] from 1996–2005 and Professor of medicine at [[University of Washington]] from 2005 until his death and president of the [[Infectious Diseases Society of America]] from 1993–4. He was also the editor of two highly regarded medical references "The Medical Management of AIDS." and "The Sanford Guide to Antimicrobial Therapy". He also gave the always popular and well attended annual update in Infectious Diseases at the [[American College of Physicians]] annual meeting as well as the clinical case presentations at the [[Infectious Diseases Society of America]] annual meeting. Sande died from complications of [[Multiple Myeloma]] in 2007. ==Selected bibliography== {{refbegin}} *{{cite journal |last=Sande |first=Merle A |author2=Ronald Allan |date=July 2004 |title=Treatment of HIV/AIDS: do the dilemmas only increase? |journal=[[Journal of the American Medical Association|JAMA]] |volume=292 |issue=2 |pages=266–8 |pmid = 15249576 |doi = 10.1001/jama.292.2.266 }} *{{cite journal |last=Trachtenberg |first=Joel D |author2=Sande Merle A |date=July 2002 |title=Emerging resistance to nonnucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors: a warning and a challenge |journal=[[Journal of the American Medical Association|JAMA]] |volume=288 |issue=2 |pages=239–41 |pmid = 12095382 |doi = 10.1001/jama.288.2.239 }} {{refend}} ==References== *{{cite journal |last=Acuña L |first=Guillermo |date=February 2008 |title=A giant in Infectious Diseases has died: Merle A. Sande, MACP, FIDSA |journal=Revista chilena de infectología : órgano oficial de la Sociedad Chilena de Infectología |volume=25 |issue=1 |pages=13 |pmid=18273516 |doi=10.4067/s0716-10182008000100001 |language=es}} ==External links== * [https://www.nytimes.com/2007/11/22/us/22sande.html obituaries New York Times Obituary] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110717002702/http://www.idsociety.org/newsArticle.aspx?id=9078 IDSA Newsletter Obituary] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sande, Merle}} [[Category:1939 births]] [[Category:2007 deaths]] [[Category:American infectious disease physicians]] [[Category:Deaths from cancer in Washington (state)]] [[Category:University of Washington alumni]] [[Category:University of Virginia School of Medicine faculty]] [[Category:University of Utah faculty]] [[Category:University of California, San Francisco faculty]] [[Category:University of Washington faculty]] [[Category:Deaths from multiple myeloma]] [[Category:HIV/AIDS researchers]]

{{more footnotes|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Michael Doucet | image = 2016MichaelDoucet.jpg | alt = White-haired Michael Doucet holding a fiddle and bow in his right hand | caption = Michael Doucet at the Minnesota State Fair, 2016 | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Michael Louis Doucet | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1951|02|14|mf=yes}} | birth_place = [[Scott, Louisiana|Scott]], Louisiana, U.S. | genre = [[Cajun music|Cajun]] | occupation = Singer, musician | instrument = [[Cajun fiddle]] | years_active = 1975–present | label = [[Arhoolie Records|Arhoolie]], [[Swallow Records|Swallow]], [[Rounder Records|Rounder]], [[Smithsonian Folkways]], [[Compass Records|Compass]], [[Yep Roc Records|Yep Roc]] | associated_acts = [[BeauSoleil]], Savoy Doucet Cajun Band, Fiddlers 4 | website = {{URL|www.beausoleilmusic.com}} }}
'''Michael Louis Doucet''' (born February 14, 1951) is an American singer-songwriter and musician best known as the founder for the Cajun band [[BeauSoleil]].
==Career== Doucet was born in [[Scott, Louisiana|Scott]], Louisiana. He learned banjo at age six, guitar at eight, and belonged to a Cajun rock band with his cousin, [[Zachary Richard]], at twelve. In his early 20s, Doucet and his cousin went to France, and when he got home he added violin to his music studies. Violin became his primary instrument, though he also plays accordion and mandolin.<ref name="Humphrey">{{cite web|last1=Humphrey|first1=Mark A.|title=Michael Doucet|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/michael-doucet-mn0000886101/biography|website=AllMusic|accessdate=4 April 2017}}</ref>
In 1975, he started the Cajun band Coteau, and two years later he started [[BeauSoleil]] with Kenneth Richard and Sterling Richard. Beausoleil plays an eclectic combination of traditional [[Cajun music]], blues, country, jazz, and [[zydeco]]. Doucet has been a member of a more traditional Cajun band, the Savoy-Doucet Cajun Band with [[Ann Savoy]] and [[Marc Savoy]], and Fiddlers 4 with [[Darol Anger]], [[Rushad Eggleston]], and [[Bruce Molsky]]. He began teaching in 1977 at the University of Southwestern Louisiana.<ref name="Humphrey" />
==Awards and honors== [[File:AccordionMichaelDoucet.jpg|thumb|upright|Doucet on accordion]] In 1975, Doucet received an NEA Folk Arts Apprenticeship Grant to study Cajun fiddle styles from masters such as [[Varise Conner]], Hector Duhon, [[Canray Fontenot]], Lionel LeLeux, and [[Dennis McGee]].
Doucet is a recipient of a 2005 [[National Heritage Fellowship]] awarded by the [[National Endowment for the Arts]], which is the United States' highest honor in the folk and traditional arts.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.arts.gov/honors/heritage/year/2005 |title=NEA National Heritage Fellowships 2005 |author=<!--Not stated--> |website=www.arts.gov |publisher=National Endowment for the Arts |access-date=22 October 2017}}</ref><ref name="Humphrey" /> Two years later, he was named a USA Collins Family Foundation Fellow and awarded a $50,000 grant by [[United States Artists]], a public charity that supports and promotes the work of American artists.

}} '''Michele Marie Bachmann''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|b|ɑː|k|m|ən}};A pronunciation of {{IPAc-en|ˈ|b|ɑː|x|m|ən}} would be closer to the German original, and some English speakers may use it, but for most [http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/magazinemonitor/2011/06/how_to_say_michele_bachmann.shtml including Bachmann] {{IPAslink|x}} is pronounced {{IPAslink|k}} after a vowel. née '''Amble'''; born April 6, 1956){{cite news|title = Elections 2008|work = Chicago Sun-Times|date = October 23, 2008|url = http://elections.suntimes.com/dynamic/external/pre-election/bios/55336.html?SITE=ILCHSELN&SECTION=POLITICS&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT|accessdate = October 24, 2008|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110111140615/http://elections.suntimes.com/dynamic/external/pre-election/bios/55336.html?SITE=ILCHSELN&SECTION=POLITICS&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT|archivedate = January 11, 2011|df = mdy-all}} is an American politician. A member of the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]], she is a former member of the [[United States House of Representatives]], who represented [[Minnesota's 6th congressional district]] from 2007 to 2015. The district includes several of the northern suburbs of the [[Minneapolis–Saint Paul|Twin Cities]], as well as [[St. Cloud, Minnesota|St. Cloud]]. Bachmann was a candidate for the Republican nomination in the [[United States presidential election, 2012|2012 U.S. presidential election]],[http://video.foxnews.com/v/4605983/michele-bachmann-eyeing-2012 "Bachmann Eyeing Presidency"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160306155019/http://video.foxnews.com/v/4605983/michele-bachmann-eyeing-2012 |date=March 6, 2016 }}, Fox News, March 24, 2011 winning the [[Iowa Straw Poll|Ames Straw Poll]] in August 2011 but dropping out in January 2012 after finishing in sixth place in the [[Republican Party presidential primaries, 2012|Iowa caucuses]]. She previously served in the [[Minnesota Senate]] and is the first Republican woman to represent the state in Congress.{{cite news|title=Minnesota's New Representatives; Michele Bachmann|quote=The first Republican congresswoman from Minnesota says she'll be there as a conservative, not a lightning rod for controversy.|work=[[Star Tribune]]|location=Minneapolis|date=November 17, 2006|first=Kevin|last=Diaz}} She is a supporter of the [[Tea Party movement]]{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2011/01/25/unusual-bachmann-rebuttal-scramble-gop-message-obama-address/#ixzz1C5GwyE2H |title={{-'}}Unusual' Bachmann Rebuttal Could Scramble GOP Message on Obama Address |publisher=Fox News|date=April 7, 2010 |accessdate=March 26, 2011}} and a founder of the House [[Tea Party Caucus]].{{cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/itsallpolitics/2010/11/08/131167261/house-gop-names-transition-team-snubs-bachmann|first=Frank|last=James|publisher=National Public Radio|title=House GOP Names Transition Team; Snubs Michele Bachmann}} {{TOC limit}} ==Early life, education, and early career== Bachmann was born Michele Marie Amble in [[Waterloo, Iowa]], "into a family of Norwegian Lutheran Democrats";[http://blogs.desmoinesregister.com/dmr/index.php/2009/10/20/bachmann-talks-about-2012/ "Bachmann Talks about 2012"] {{webarchive |url=https://archive.is/20120718103250/http://blogs.desmoinesregister.com/dmr/index.php/2009/10/20/bachmann-talks-about-2012/ |date=July 18, 2012 }}, ''[[The Des Moines Register]]'', October 20, 2009. her family moved from Iowa to Minnesota when she was 13 years old.Ode, Kim (July 22, 2007), [https://archive.is/20150426040337/http://www.startribune.com/politics/11763126.html "Michele Bachmann: Watching her step"], ''Star Tribune'' (Minneapolis), retrieved April 25, 2015. After her parents divorced, Bachmann's father, David John Amble, moved to California, and Bachmann was raised by her mother, Arlene Jean (née Johnson), who worked at the First National Bank in [[Anoka, Minnesota]].{{cite web|url=http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~battle/reps/bachmann.htm|title=Michele Bachmann ancestry|website=ancestry.com|accessdate=May 8, 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://wcfcourier.com/iowacaucus/profiles/michele_bachmann/michele-bachmann-visits-waterloo-talks-about-how-waterloo-cf-formed/article_51be1ca2-17c3-11e1-9f59-001cc4c03286.html |title=Caucus News |publisher=Wcfcourier.com |date= |accessdate=August 10, 2014}} Her mother remarried when Bachmann was a teenager; the new marriage resulted in a family with nine children.{{cite news |work=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=July 7, 2011 |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/news/michele-bachmanns-holy-war-20110622|title=Michele Bachmann's Holy War|first=Matt|last=Taibbi|authorlink=Matt Taibbi}} She graduated from [[Anoka High School]] in 1974 and, after graduation, spent one summer working on [[kibbutz]] [[Be'eri]] in Israel.Mitelman, Jenna (March 24, 2010), [http://tcjewfolk.com/michele-bachmann-israel/ "Michele Bachmann on her love for Israel, and considering herself Jewish"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160910051833/http://tcjewfolk.com/michele-bachmann-israel/ |date=September 10, 2016 }}, ''TC Jewfolk'', retrieved March 26, 2011 In 1978, she graduated from [[Winona State University]] with a B.A.{{cite web|title = Bachmann, Michele – Biographical Information|publisher=United States Congress|year = 2008|url = http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=B001256|accessdate =November 30, 2008}} In 1979, Bachmann was a member of the first class of the [[O. W. Coburn School of Law]], then a part of [[Oral Roberts University]] (ORU). While there, Bachmann studied with [[John Eidsmoe]], whom she described in 2011 as "one of the professors who had a great influence on me".{{cite news |title=The Transformation of Michele Bachmann |last=Lizza |first=Ryan |authorlink=Ryan Lizza |url=http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2011/08/15/110815fa_fact_lizza?currentPage=all |newspaper=[[The New Yorker]] |date=August 15, 2011 |accessdate=August 2, 2011}} Bachmann worked as a research assistant on Eidsmoe's 1987 book ''Christianity and the Constitution'', which argues that the United States was founded as a Christian [[theocracy]] and should become one again. In 1986 Bachmann received a [[Juris Doctor|J.D.]] degree from Oral Roberts University. She was a member of the ORU law school's final graduating class, and was part of a group of faculty, staff, and students who moved the ORU law school library to what is now [[Regent University]].{{cite web|url=http://regentlawnews.blogspot.com/2009/11/congresswoman-michelle-bachmann-speaks.html |title=Congresswoman Michele Bachmann Speaks at Regent Law Chapel |website=Regent Law News |date=November 24, 2009 |accessdate=January 13, 2010}} In 1988, Bachmann received an [[Master of Laws|LL.M.]] degree in [[tax law]] from [[William & Mary Law School]].{{Cite news|title=About Michele Bachmann|url=http://projects.washingtonpost.com/congress/members/B001256|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=March 26, 2011}} From 1988 to 1993 she worked as an attorney for the [[Internal Revenue Service]] (IRS). She left the IRS to become a full-time motherDuchschere, Kevin (January 1, 2005). "Senator, mother, rising star". ''Star Tribune'' (Minneapolis). when her fourth child was born.{{cite news |work=[[The New York Times]]|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/22/us/politics/22bachmann.html |title=Roots of Bachmann's Ambition Began at Home|first=Sheryl Gay|last=Stolberg |date= June 21, 2011 }} ==Personal life== === Family === {{anchor|Marcus Bachmann}} [[File:Marcus Bachmann Michele 2011 Shankbone.JPG|thumb|Husband Marcus Bachmann and Michele at the 2011 [[Time 100]] gala, where Michele was an honoree]] Michele Marie Amble was born in [[Waterloo, Iowa]] on April 6, 1956, to [[Norwegian-American]] {{cite web|url=http://www.vg.no/nyheter/utenriks/president-barack-obama/seier-til-norskaettede-titan-michelle/a/10081271/|title=Seier til norskættede "Titan-Michelle"|author=May Linn Gjerding|website=VG|accessdate=May 8, 2015}} parents David John Amble (1929–2003) and "Arlene" Jean Amble ([[name at birth|née]] Johnson) (born c. 1932).{{cite web |url=http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~battle/reps/bachmann.htm |title=Michele Bachmann ancestry |website=RootsWeb |publisher=Ancestry.com |accessdate=May 29, 2013}} One pair of her great-great-great grandparents, Melchior and Martha Munson, left [[Sogndal]] in [[Norway]] and arrived in Wisconsin in 1857.{{cite web|url=http://2012.republican-candidates.org/Bachmann/Biography.php|title=Bachmann Biography|author=politicks Org|date=May 8, 2015|website=republican-candidates.org|accessdate=May 8, 2015}} She was still a young girl when her father, an engineer, moved the family to [[Brooklyn Park, Minnesota]]. She was 14 years old when her parents filed for divorce. Her father remarried and moved to California, and young Michele and her mother Jean moved to [[Anoka, Minnesota]]. Her mother remarried three years later to widower Raymond J. LaFave.{{cite web |url=http://2012.republican-candidates.org/Bachmann/Childhood.php |title=Bachmann's Childhood |publisher=2012 Republican Candidates |accessdate=May 29, 2013}} In 1978, she married Marcus Bachmann, now a clinical therapist with a [[Master of Arts|master's degree]] from [[Regent University]] and a [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] from [[Union Institute & University|Union Graduate School]],{{Cite news|title=The Education of Marcus Bachmann|url=http://thecaucus.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/07/18/the-education-of-marcus-bachmann/|date=July 18, 2011|first=Sheryl Gay|last=Stolberg|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=August 19, 2011}} whom she met while they were undergraduates.{{Cite news|title=Michele Bachmann| first=Ashley |last=Parker|url=http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/b/michele_m_bachmann/index.html|date=April 4, 2011|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=April 4, 2011}} After she received an LL.M. in taxation from William & Mary School of Law in 1988, the couple moved to [[Stillwater, Minnesota]], a town of 18,000 near [[Saint Paul, Minnesota|Saint Paul]], where they run a Christian counseling center that provided gay conversion therapy.{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2011/07/10/marcus-bachmann-s-controversial-gay-therapy-and-how-it-affects-michele-s-campaign.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=August 11, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160515150140/http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2011/07/10/marcus-bachmann-s-controversial-gay-therapy-and-how-it-affects-michele-s-campaign.html |archivedate=May 15, 2016 |df=mdy }} Bachmann and her husband have five children: Lucas, Harrison, Elisa, Caroline, and Sophia. Bachmann said in a 2011 town hall meeting that she suffered a [[miscarriage]] after the birth of their second child, Harrison, an event she said shaped her [[pro-life]] views.Shear, Michael D. (June 30, 2011). [http://thecaucus.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/06/30/bachmann-says-views-on-abortion-shaped-by-miscarriage/?scp=8&sq=syed%20fai&st=cse "Bachmann's Views on Abortion Shaped by Miscarriage"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130518134356/http://thecaucus.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/06/30/bachmann-says-views-on-abortion-shaped-by-miscarriage/?scp=8&sq=syed%20fai&st=cse |date=May 18, 2013 }}. ''[[The New York Times]]''. Bachmann and her husband have also provided [[foster care]] to 23 other children,{{cite news|newspaper=Naples Sun Times|location=Naples, FL|last=La Paglia|first=Bernadette|title=Senator lectures on educational complacency|publisher=Scripps Interactive Newspapers Group|date=October 6, 2004|url = http://www.zwire.com/site/news.cfm?newsid=13073398&BRD=2605&PAG=461&dept_id=523946&rfi=6|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070823164320/http://www.zwire.com/site/news.cfm?newsid=13073398&BRD=2605&PAG=461&dept_id=523946&rfi=6|archivedate=August 23, 2007|accessdate=August 19, 2011}} all teenage girls. The Bachmanns were licensed from 1992 to 2000 to handle up to three foster children at a time; the last child arrived in 1998. The Bachmanns began by providing short-term care for girls with [[eating disorder]]s who were patients in a University of Minnesota program. The Bachmann home was legally defined as a treatment home, with a daily reimbursement rate per child from the state. Some girls stayed a few months, others more than a year. She is a former beauty pageant queen.{{Cite news|url=http://thehill.com/capital-living/24096-understanding-the-beauty-queen-politician|title=Understanding the beauty-queen politician|last=Perks|first=Ashley|date=September 15, 2008|work=TheHill|access-date=August 23, 2018|language=en}} === Citizenship === In May 2012, it was reported that Marcus Bachmann had registered for Swiss citizenship and after it was finalized, Michele Bachmann automatically became a citizen as well.{{cite news|url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0512/76072.html|work=Politico|date=May 8, 2012|accessdate=May 8, 2012|title=Michele Bachmann claims Swiss citizenship|last=Mak|first=Tim}} The Bachmanns and their three youngest children were granted citizenship on March 19, 2012. They had been eligible for this under [[Swiss nationality law]] because Marcus Bachmann's parents were Swiss. Bachmann denied that she or her husband had applied for Swiss citizenship, saying that her husband had already been a dual citizen as the son of Swiss immigrants, and that she had automatically acquired Swiss citizenship under then-current Swiss law when she married him in 1978. But in May 2012, when a [[Schweizer Fernsehen|Swiss Television]] reporter said to her "I understand you just got Swiss citizenship", Bachmann's reply was: "Yes, we did."{{cite news |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6vn0sBdE3W8|title=Interview Michele Bachmann on Swiss Citizenship – extended version |last= |first= |date=May 10, 2012|publisher=[[Schweizer Fernsehen|Swiss Television]] |agency=[[SRG SSR]] |accessdate=May 11, 2012}} Marcus Bachmann did not register the marriage with the Swiss authorities until 2012.{{cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2012/may/10/news/la-pn-bachmann-downplays-swiss-citizenship-20120510 |title=Bachmann Downplays Swiss Citizenship |date=May 10, 2012|publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=June 25, 2012 |first=Kim |last=Geiger}} Within two days of the first reports of Bachmann's dual citizenship,{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/may/11/michele-bachman-swiss-citizenship |title=Michele Bachman decides not be Swiss after all |work=[[The Guardian]]|location=London|agency=Associated Press|date=May 11, 2012|accessdate=May 11, 2012}} she announced that she had written to the Swiss consulate to have her Swiss citizenship withdrawn.{{cite news |url=http://www.seattlepi.com/news/article/Michele-Bachmann-giving-up-Swiss-citizenship-3549508.php |title=Michele Bachmann giving up Swiss citizenship |last=Karnowski |first=Steve |date=May 10, 2012|work=[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]] |agency=Associated Press |accessdate=June 25, 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120511032942/http://www.seattlepi.com/news/article/Michele-Bachmann-giving-up-Swiss-citizenship-3549508.php|archivedate=May 11, 2012 }} ===Religion=== Bachmann was a longtime member of Salem Lutheran Church ([[Wisconsin Evangelical Lutheran Synod]]) in Stillwater. She and her husband withdrew their membership on June 21, 2011, just before she officially began her presidential campaign. They had not attended the church for over two years.Marrapodi, Eric (July 15, 2011). [http://religion.blogs.cnn.com/2011/07/15/michele-bachmann-officially-leaves-her-church/?iref=obnetwork "Michele Bachmann officially leaves her church"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304093749/http://religion.blogs.cnn.com/2011/07/15/michele-bachmann-officially-leaves-her-church/?iref=obnetwork |date=March 4, 2016 }}. ''CNN Belief Blog''. CNN. More recently, according to friends, the Bachmanns began attending [[Bob Merritt#Eagle Brook pastor|Eagle Brook Church]], an [[Evangelical Protestant]] Baptist church closer to their home.https://www.nytimes.com/2011/07/17/us/politics/17bachmann.html. ({{cite news |url=http://www.religionnews.com/index.php?/polls/poll_americans_are_unsure_on_politicians_faith2/ |title=Poll: Americans want religious presidents, but are vague on details |accessdate=August 6, 2011 |date=July 25, 2011 |publisher=Religion News Service |first=Nicole |last=Neroulias |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110912195201/http://www.religionnews.com/index.php?%2Fpolls%2Fpoll_americans_are_unsure_on_politicians_faith2%2F |archivedate=September 12, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}). Bachmann has cited theologian [[Francis Schaeffer]] as a "profound influence" on her life and her husband's, especially his film series ''[[How Should We Then Live?]]''. She has also described ''Total Truth: Liberating Christianity from Its Cultural Captivity'' by [[Nancy Pearcey]] as a "wonderful" book. Journalist [[Ryan Lizza]] has argued that Bachmann's worldview is deeply influenced by the Christian movement known as [[Dominionism]], citing the influence of Schaeffer and Pearcey as evidence. Others have criticized Lizza's article, especially its connection of Schaeffer with Dominionism.{{cite news |url=http://www.firstthings.com/onthesquare/2011/08/a-journalism-lesson-for-the-new-yorker/joe-carter |title=A Journalism Lesson for ''The New Yorker'' |last=Carter |first=Joe |date=August 10, 2011 |newspaper=[[First Things]] |accessdate=August 13, 2011}}{{cite news |title=In Bachmann Attack, Ryan Lizza Smears Francis Schaeffer |last=Domenech |first=Ben |authorlink=Ben Domenech |url=http://newledger.com/2011/08/in-bachmann-attack-ryan-lizza-smears-francis-schaeffer/ |newspaper=[[The New Ledger]] |date=August 8, 2011 |accessdate=August 13, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111007034948/http://newledger.com/2011/08/in-bachmann-attack-ryan-lizza-smears-francis-schaeffer/ |archivedate=October 7, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}{{cite web |last=Hankins |first=Barry |date=August 15, 2011 |title=The New Yorker and Evangelicalism |url=http://spectator.org/archives/2011/08/15/the-new-yorker-and-evangelical |website="The American Spectator" |postscript={{inconsistent citations}} |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111010040658/http://spectator.org/archives/2011/08/15/the-new-yorker-and-evangelical |archivedate=October 10, 2011 |df=mdy-all }} Religion writer [[Sarah Posner]] broadly concurs with Lizza, pointing to the influence of [[Christian Reconstructionism|Christian Reconstructionists]] [[Herb Titus]] and [[Rousas John Rushdoony|R. J. Rushdoony]] on Bachmann via the curriculum at O. W. Coburn School of Law.{{cite web |url=http://www.religiondispatches.org/archive/politics/4838/god%E2%80%99s_law_is_the_only_law%3A_the_genesis_of_michele_bachmann/ |title=God's Law is the Only Law: The Genesis of Michele Bachmann |last=Posner |first=Sarah |authorlink=Sarah Posner |date=July 11, 2011 |website=[[Religion Dispatches]] |accessdate=August 8, 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://www.religiondispatches.org/dispatches/sarahposner/4977/perry%27s_challenge_to_bachmann_for_religious_right_vote/ |title=Perry's Challenge to Bachmann for Religious Right Vote |last=Posner |first=Sarah |authorlink=Sarah Posner |date=August 8, 2011 |website=[[Religion Dispatches]] |accessdate=August 8, 2011}} ===Businesses=== Bachmann and her husband own a [[Christian counseling]] practice, Bachmann & Associates.{{cite web|title=Biography|url=http://bachmann.house.gov/Biography/|website=Congresswoman Michele Bachmann|publisher=[[U.S. House of Representatives]]|accessdate=April 19, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110411134806/http://bachmann.house.gov/Biography/|archivedate=April 11, 2011|df=mdy-all}}{{cite web| title = Meet Dr. Bachmann| publisher=Bachmann & Associates Inc.| url = http://www.bachmanncounseling.com/drbachmann/| accessdate =January 5, 2010 }} The clinic is run by her husband, who has a Ph.D. with "a concentration in clinical psychology"{{cite news| url=http://thecaucus.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/07/18/the-education-of-marcus-bachmann/ | work=The New York Times | title=The Education of Marcus Bachmann | date=July 18, 2011}} from [[Union Institute & University|Union Graduate School]]. Marcus Bachmann is not a licensed [[clinical psychologist]] in Minnesota.{{cite news|last=Kennedy|first=Tony|title=Marcus Bachmann says his clinics not anti-gay|url=http://www.startribune.com/politics/statelocal/125610083.html|accessdate=August 10, 2011|newspaper=Star Tribune|date=July 15, 2011}} The clinic received nearly $30,000 from Minnesota government agencies between 2006 and 2010 in addition to at least $137,000 in federal payments and $24,000 in government grants for counselor training.{{cite news|last=Bakst|first=Brian|title=Public money puts Republican Bachmann on defensive|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/wireStory?id=13959369|accessdate=August 10, 2011|agency=Associated Press|publisher=ABC News|date=June 29, 2011}} When asked about the subject in an interview, Bachmann indicated that she and her husband had not benefited at taxpayer expense, saying, "the money that went to the clinic was actually training money for employees".{{cite news |work=Los Angeles Times |title=Michele Bachmann denies benefiting from government aid |author=Richard A. Serrano |date=June 27, 2011 |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/nation/la-na-michele-bachmann-20110627,0,3115941.story }} Marcus Bachmann has denied allegations that Bachmann & Associates provides [[conversion therapy]], a controversial psychological treatment repudiated by the [[American Psychological Association]] that attempts to transform homosexuals into heterosexuals.{{Cite news|url=http://minnesotaindependent.com/59781/bachmanns-christian-counseling-clinic-receives-state-funds |work=Minnesota Independent |title=Bachmann's Christian counseling clinic receives state funds |first=Andy |last=Birkey |date=June 4, 2010 |accessdate=July 9, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718212144/http://minnesotaindependent.com/59781/bachmanns-christian-counseling-clinic-receives-state-funds |archivedate=July 18, 2011 }} A former client of Bachmann's clinic and a hidden camera investigator with the activist group [[Truth Wins Out]] have said that therapists at the clinic do engage in such practices,{{cite news| url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2011/07/12/clinic-tied-to-bachmann-questioned-over-therapies/| title=Clinic tied to Bachmann questioned over therapies | agency=[[Associated Press]] | date=July 12, 2011 | accessdate=July 13, 2011 | author=Bakst, Brian | work=Fox News}}{{cite web | url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0711/58741.html | title=ABC News probes gay 'cure' claims about Bachmann clinic | website=[[Politico]] | date=July 11, 2011 | accessdate=July 13, 2011 | author=Haberman, Maggie}} but columnist Mariah Blake of ''[[The Nation]]'' has suggested the hidden camera investigator may have been intentionally baiting the therapist to say something controversial.{{cite news|url=http://www.thenation.com/article/161883/%E2%80%98god-has-created-you-heterosexuality%E2%80%99-clinics-owned-michele-bachmann%E2%80%99s-husband-practi|title={{-'}}God Has Created You for Heterosexuality': Clinics Owned by Michele Bachmann's Husband Practice Ex-Gay Therapy|work=[[The Nation]]|date=July 8, 2011|accessdate=July 9, 2011|last=Blake|first=Mariah}} In a subsequent interview with the ''[[Star Tribune]]'', Marcus Bachmann did not deny that he or other counselors at his clinic used the technique but said they did so only at a client's request. In personal financial disclosure reports for 2006 through 2009, Bachmann reported earning $32,500 to $105,000 from a farm that was owned at the time by her ailing father-in-law, Paul Bachmann. The farm received $260,000 in federal crop and disaster subsidies between 1995 and 2008.{{cite news | url=http://articles.latimes.com/2011/jun/26/nation/la-na-bachmann-20110626 | title=Bachmann's had her share of government aid |work=Los Angeles Times | date=June 26, 2011 | accessdate=July 4, 2011 | first=Melanie|last=Mason|first2=Matea|last2=Gold}} Bachmann said that in 2006–2009, her husband acted as a trustee of the farm for his dying father and so, out of "an abundance of caution", she claimed the farm as income in financial disclosures, though it was her in-laws who profited from the farm during that period.{{cite news|work=[[Boston Herald]]|title=Michele Bachmann bomblets raising eyebrows|first=Calvin|last=Woodward|first2=Jim|last2=Drinkard|agency=Associated Press |date=June 28, 2011 |url=http://news.bostonherald.com/news/us_politics/view/20110628michele_bachmann_bomblets_raising_eyebrows/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120315194613/http://news.bostonherald.com/news/us_politics/view/20110628michele_bachmann_bomblets_raising_eyebrows/|archivedate=March 15, 2012 }} == Early political activism == Bachmann grew up in a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] family, but she says she became a Republican during her senior year at Winona State. She told the Minneapolis ''[[Star Tribune]]'' that she was reading [[Gore Vidal]]'s 1973 novel ''[[Burr (novel)|Burr]]'': "He was kind of mocking the Founding Fathers and I just thought, I just remember reading the book, putting it in my lap, looking out the window and thinking, 'You know what? I don't think I am a Democrat. I must be a Republican.{{'"}}[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0w0I1ulhtC8 "Michele Bachmann speech, Troy MI Dec 28, 2010 Part 1/2"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121120180733/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0w0I1ulhtC8 |date=November 20, 2012 }} [[[Flash Video]]] at 6:50–8:10, YouTube, retrieved March 25, 2011 While still a
