url=http://www.gop.com/News/Read.aspx?ID=6549 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061021221424/http://www.gop.com/News/Read.aspx?ID=6549 | archivedate=October 21, 2006 | title=Michele Bachmann | publisher=GOP.COM | date=September 7, 2006 | accessdate=July 25, 2011}} They prayed outside of clinics and engaged in [[sidewalk counseling]],{{cite web|title=Michele Bachmann for Congress| url=http://www.gop.com/News/Read.aspx?ID=6549|date=September 7, 2006|website=Candidate Focus|publisher=[[Republican National Committee]]| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061021221424/http://www.gop.com/News/Read.aspx?ID=6549|archivedate=October 21, 2006|accessdate=March 26, 2011}} a pro-life protest activity in which activists approach people entering abortion clinics in an attempt to dissuade women from obtaining abortions.{{cite web|title=No Taxpayer Funding for Abortion Act|url=http://www.patheos.com/Resources/Additional-Resources/No-Taxpayer-Funding-for-Abortion-Act-Roy-Speckhardt-02-14-2011.html|last=Speckhardt|first=Roy|authorlink=Roy Speckhardt|date=February 14, 2011|website=A Humanist View|publisher=[[Patheos]]|accessdate=July 17, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110218014505/http://www.patheos.com/Resources/Additional-Resources/No-Taxpayer-Funding-for-Abortion-Act-Roy-Speckhardt-02-14-2011.html|archivedate=February 18, 2011|df=mdy-all}} Since then, Bachmann has made statements supportive of sidewalk counseling.{{cite news | url=http://www.christianpost.com/news/bachmann-tells-pro-lifers-their-efforts-are-not-a-waste-48643/ | title=Bachmann Tells Pro-Lifers Their Efforts Are Not a Waste | date=January 25, 2011 | accessdate=July 25, 2011 | author=Stephanie Samuel | location=Washington}} Bachmann was a supporter of [[Jimmy Carter]] in 1976, and she and her husband worked on his campaign.{{cite web | first =Daniel | last =Libit | title =The Shuttle: Rep. Michele Bachmann|date=June 13, 2008 | website=[[Politico (newspaper)|Politico]] |accessdate=February 15, 2011| url = http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0608/11048.html}} During Carter's presidency, Bachmann became disappointed with his liberal approach to public policy, support for legalized abortion and economic decisions she held responsible for increased gas prices. In the 1980 presidential election, she voted for [[Ronald Reagan]] and worked for his campaign.{{cite web | first =Zoe | last =Sandvig | title =High-minded and high-heeled|date=October 4, 2008 | website=[[World (magazine)|World]] |accessdate=February 15, 2011| url = http://www.worldmag.com/articles/14445}} Her political activism gained media attention at a pro-life protest in 1991. She and approximately 30 other pro-life citizens went to a [[Ramsey County, Minnesota|Ramsey County]] Board meeting where a $3 million appropriation was to go to build a morgue for the county at St. Paul-Ramsey Medical Center (now [[Regions Hospital]]). The Medical Center performed abortions and employed [[pro-choice]] activist [[Jane Elizabeth Hodgson|Jane Hodgson]]. Bachmann attended the meeting to protest public tax dollars going to the hospital; speaking to the ''Star Tribune'', she said that "in effect, since 1973, I have been a landlord of an abortion clinic, and I don't like that distinction".Prince, Pat (December 18, 1991), "Abortion issue clouds med center lease plan", ''Star Tribune'' (Minneapolis, MN) In 1993, she and other parents started the K-12 New Heights Charter School in Stillwater. The publicly funded school's charter mandated that it be non-sectarian in all programs and practices, but the school soon developed a strong Christian orientation. Parents of students at the school complained and the superintendent of schools warned Bachmann that the school was in violation of state law. Six months after the school's founding Bachmann resigned and the Christian orientation was removed from the curriculum, allowing the school to keep its charter.{{cite web | url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2011/06/14/michele-bachmanns-unrivaled-extremism-gay-rights-to-religion.html | title=Bachmann's Unrivaled Extremism | website=[[Daily Beast]] | date=June 14, 2011 | accessdate=June 23, 2011 | author=Goldberg, Michelle | authorlink=Michelle Goldberg}}{{cite news|last=Lizza|first=Ryan|title=Leap of Faith: The making of a Republican front-runner|url=http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2011/08/15/110815fa_fact_lizza?printable=true¤tPage=all|accessdate=August 10, 2011|newspaper=The New Yorker|date=August 15, 2011}}{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/22/us/politics/22bachmann.html?_r=0| title=Roots of Bachmann's Ambition Began at Home | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=June 21, 2011 | accessdate=April 26, 2015 | author=Stolberg, Sheryl Gay}} Bachmann began speaking against a state-mandated set of educational standards, which propelled her into the world of politics.{{cite news|title=Full Transcript: Michele Bachmann Speaks To NPR|url=https://www.npr.org/2011/06/29/137496659/full-transcript-michele-bachmann-speaks-to-npr|publisher=[[NPR]]|accessdate=August 14, 2011|date=June 29, 2011}} Bachmann became a critic and opponent of Minnesota's [[School-to-work transition|School-to-Work]] policies. In a 1999 column, she wrote: "School-to-Work alters the basic mission and purpose of K-12 academic education away from traditional broad-based academic studies geared toward maximizing intellectual achievement of the individual. Instead, School-to-Work utilizes the school day to promote children's acquisition of workplace skills, viewing children as trainees for increased economic productivity."{{cite web | last =Bachmann | first =Michele | title = School-to-Work: The Heart of Educational Reform| publisher=Minnesota Family Institute |date=October 8, 1999 | url = https://groups.yahoo.com/group/mn-politics-announce/message/412 |accessdate=November 13, 2006 }} In November 1999, she and four other Republicans were candidates, as the "Slate of Five", in an election for the school board of Stillwater. All five lost. ==Minnesota Senate== In 2000, Bachmann defeated 18-year incumbent [[Gary Laidig]] for the Republican nomination for State Senator for Minnesota District 56. In the November 2000 general election, she defeated Ted Thompson of the [[Minnesota Democratic-Farmer-Labor Party]] (DFL) and Lyno Sullivan of the [[Minnesota Independence Party]], to win the seat. Two years later, in November 2002, after redistricting due to the [[2000 United States Census|2000 Census]], Bachmann defeated another incumbent, State Senator Jane Krentz of the DFL, in the newly drawn State Senate District 52. In office, Bachmann's agenda focused on the cultural conservative issues of opposition to abortion and gay marriage. === Same-sex marriage constitutional amendment === On November 20, 2003, Bachmann and Representative [[Mary Liz Holberg]] proposed a constitutional amendment that would bar the state from legally recognizing [[same-sex marriage]].{{cite news | first = Mark | last = Brunswick | title = Keeping gay marriage outside law; Legislators propose constitutional prohibition|date=November 21, 2003 |work=Star Tribune|location=Minneapolis}} In 2004, Bachmann and a coalition of religious leaders announced plans for a "Minnesota for Marriage" rally.{{cite news | first = Mark | last = Brunswick | title = Same-sex marriage bill heads to House floor|date=March 12, 2004 |work=Star Tribune|location=Minneapolis}} Bachmann's effort to place a marriage amendment on a referendum ballot in 2004 ultimately failed. She resurrected her proposal in March 2005,{{cite news | first = Pat | last = Doyle | title = Bill would order vote on ban of same-sex marriage|date=March 9, 2005 |work=Star Tribune|location=Minneapolis}} but it stalled indefinitely in a senate committee that April.{{cite web | url=http://www.cnsnews.com/Culture/archive/200504/CUL20050421a.html | title =Minnesotans rally in defense of marriage | first =Susan | last =Jones | publisher=[[Cybercast News Service]] |accessdate=December 16, 2006 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070212223013/http://www.cnsnews.com/Culture/archive/200504/CUL20050421a.html |archivedate = February 12, 2007}} === Assistant Minority Leader === In November 2004, Republican Senate Minority Leader [[Dick Day]] appointed Bachmann as Assistant Minority Leader in charge of Policy for the Senate Republican Caucus.{{cite news | publisher=St. Paul Pioneer Press | title = Minnesota Bachmann named to Senate post |date=November 6, 2004}} In July 2005, the Republican Caucus removed her from her leadership position. Bachmann said that disagreements with Day over her anti-tax stance were the reason for her ouster.{{cite web | title = Bachmann's Anti-Tax, Pro-Life Stance Leads To Ouster From Senate Leadership | publisher=Michele Bachmann for U.S. Congress |date=July 20, 2005 | url = http://www.michelebachmann.com/article.asp?ARTICLEID=29 |accessdate=December 16, 2006 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061213205607/http://www.michelebachmann.com/article.asp?ARTICLEID=29| archivedate = December 13, 2006}} ==U.S. House of Representatives== From January 2007 to January 2015 Bachmann represented {{ushr|MN|6}}, which includes the northernmost and eastern suburbs of the [[Twin Cities]] and [[St. Cloud, Minnesota|St. Cloud]]. She is the first Republican woman to be elected to the U.S. House from Minnesota. ===110th Congress=== ====Foreign affairs==== In January 2007, a resolution was approved in the House of Representatives opposing [[U.S. President|President]] [[George W. Bush]]'s [[Iraq War troop surge of 2007|plan to increase troop levels]] in [[Iraq War|Iraq]]. Bachmann voted "No". But before supporting the proposed surge, Bachmann called for a full hearing, saying, "The American people deserve to hear and understand the merits of increasing U.S. troop presence in Iraq. Increased troop presence is justifiable if that measure would bring a swift conclusion to a difficult conflict."{{cite web |last=Diaz |first=Kevin |title=Minnesota delegation offers cool response |website=Star Tribune|location=Minneapolis|date=January 8, 2007 |url=http://www.startribune.com/587/story/923881.html |accessdate=January 9, 2007}}{{dead link|date=September 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} She hesitated to give a firm endorsement, calling the hearings "a good first step in explaining to the American people the course toward victory in Iraq".{{cite news|title=Minnesota delegation weighs in on Bush plan for more troops|first=Brady|last=Averill|url=http://www.startribune.com/587/story/931746.html|work=Star Tribune|location=Minneapolis|date=January 11, 2007 |accessdate=January 15, 2007 }}{{dead link|date=September 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} When pressed, she said she had not come to any conclusion on the matter, saying, "I don't believe we have all of the information in front of us. As a member of Congress that's why I want to go to Iraq as quickly as I can. I want to get the best information in front of me."{{cite news| url=http://minnesota.publicradio.org/display/web/2007/01/05/washpol/|publisher=Minnesota Public Radio| title=Minnesota delegation cool to use of more troops in Iraq|author=Mark Zdechlik|date=January 5, 2007 |accessdate=January 17, 2007}} ===== Member of Congressional delegation ===== In July 2007, Bachmann joined a Congressional delegation visiting [[Ireland]], [[Germany]], [[Pakistan]], [[Kuwait]], and [[Iraq]]. Bachmann met briefly (due to security concerns) with U.S. personnel in the [[Green Zone]] and upon her return she said she "was encouraged by reports of progress from Crocker, Gen. David Petraeus and other personnel in Iraq linked to the surge".{{cite news|title=Bachmann: Surge needs time|url=http://www.sctimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20070710/NEWS01/107090061/1009|first=Lawrence|last=Schumacher |date=July 10, 2007|work=St. Cloud Times}}{{dead link|date=December 2015}} She said the surge "hasn't had a chance to be in place long enough to offer a critique of how it's working. (Gen. Petraeus) said [[al-Qaida in Iraq]] is off its plan and we want to keep it that way. The surge has only been fully in place for a week or so." Bachmann also spoke of the delegation's visit to [[Islamabad]] to meet [[Prime Minister of Pakistan|Pakistani Prime Minister]] [[Shaukat Aziz|Aziz]] at the same time as the [[Lal Masjid siege|siege of Islamic fundamentalists]] at the [[Lal Masjid, Islamabad|Lal Masjid]] mosque elsewhere in the city. She reported that "The group [of U.S. Legislators] had to travel in armored vehicles and was constantly accompanied by Pakistani military ... We were all able to see extremely up close and personal what it's like to be in a region where fighting is occurring. We constantly felt like we were in need of security." Bachmann told reporters upon her return that "the dangers posed by Islamic terrorism in Iraq, Britain and Pakistan justified the continued American military presence in Iraq." She said "We don't want to see [[al-Qaida]] get a presence in the United States. Al-Qaida doesn't seem to show any signs of letting up. We have to keep that in mind." ====Higher education==== On July 11, 2007, Bachmann voted against the College Cost Reduction and Access Act that raised the maximum [[Pell grant]] from $4,310 to $5,200, lower interest rates on subsidized student loans to 3.4 percent from 6.8 percent, raise loan limits to $30,500 from $7,500, disfavor married students who file joint tax returns, provide more favorable repayment terms to students who fail to use their education to prosper financiallyUniversity of Michigan Law School, [http://www.law.umich.edu/currentstudents/financialaid/Documents/ccrafaq.pdf CCRA faq's] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120310122835/http://www.law.umich.edu/currentstudents/financialaid/Documents/ccrafaq.pdf |date=March 10, 2012 }} and favor public sector over private sector workers with much more favorable loan forgiveness benefits.FinAid [http://www.finaid.org/loans/publicservice.phtml guide to financial aide] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161104053645/http://www.finaid.org/loans/publicservice.phtml |date=November 4, 2016 }} (obtained April 19, 2011) Supporters of the bill said "it would allow more students to attend college".{{cite news|title=Bachmann votes against Pell grants bill| first=Pamela| last= Brogan| work=St. Cloud Times|date=July 12, 2007|url=http://www.sctimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20070712/NEWS01/107110049/1009}}{{Dead link|date=April 2011}} Bachmann said her opposition was because "it fails students and taxpayers with gimmicks, hidden costs and poorly targeted aid. It contains no serious reform of existing programs, and it favors the costly, government-run direct lending program over nonprofit and commercial lenders." The bill passed the House and was signed by President Bush.{{cite news|title=Fact Sheet: College Cost Reduction and Access Act of 2007|date=September 27, 2007|url=https://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/news/releases/2007/09/20070927-1.html}} ====Energy and environment==== During the summer of 2008, as national gasoline prices rose to over $4 a gallon, Bachmann became a leading Congressional advocate for increased domestic oil and natural gas exploration in the [[Arctic National Wildlife Refuge]] (ANWR) and the [[Outer Continental Shelf]].{{cite news| title = Bachmann seeks House vote on oil exploration|first=Kevin|last=Diaz|work=Star Tribune|location=Minneapolis|date=July 29, 2008|url=http://www.startribune.com/politics/statelocal/26081114.html| accessdate =January 23, 2009}} She joined ten other House Republicans and members of the media on a Congressional Energy Tour to the [[National Renewable Energy Laboratory]] in [[Golden, Colorado]], and to Alaska. The trip was set up by Arctic Power, an Alaskan [[lobbying]] group that advocates for [[ANWR drilling|ANWR development]]. The purpose of the trip was to receive a firsthand account of emerging renewable energy technologies and the prospects of increased domestic oil and natural gas production in Alaska, including ANWR.{{cite news|first=Sean |last=Cockerham |title=GOP Hopefuls get close look at ANWR |work=[[Anchorage Daily News]] |date=July 18, 2008 |url=http://www.adn.com/2008/07/18/468146/gop-hopefuls-get-close-look-at.html |accessdate=May 31, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100504184642/http://www.adn.com/2008/07/18/468146/gop-hopefuls-get-close-look-at.html |archivedate=May 4, 2010 }} Bachmann has said that [[global warming]] is "all voodoo, nonsense, hokum, a hoax"{{cite news|last1=Scheck|first1=Tom|title=Bachmann doesn't like McCain or global warming|url=http://blogs.mprnews.org/capitol-view/2008/03/bachmann_doesnt/|accessdate=April 12, 2016|publisher=Minnesota Public Radio|date=March 17, 2008}} and has been called "one of the GOP's loudest global warming skeptics".Diaz, Kevin; McAuliffe, Bill (May 3, 2009). [https://archive.is/20140106161455/http://www.startribune.com/politics/state/44270817.html "Climate debate heating up for Minnesotans in Washington"]. ''Star Tribune'' (Minneapolis). Retrieved January 5, 2014. She has said that [[carbon dioxide]] is "a natural byproduct of nature" and a beneficial gas required by plant life. She stated that because life requires carbon dioxide and it is part of the planet's life cycle, it cannot be harmful. In a statement she made on the House floor on [[Earth Day]], April 22, 2009, Bachmann stated she was against the [[cap and trade]] climate legislation, stating: "Carbon dioxide is not a harmful gas, it is a harmless gas. Carbon dioxide is natural; it is not harmful ... We're being told we have to reduce this natural substance to create an arbitrary reduction in something that is naturally occurring in the earth."{{cite web|last=Schmelzer |first=Paul |title=On climate science, Bachmann accused of 'making things up' on the House floor |website=[[Center for Independent Media|Minnesota Independent]] |date=April 24, 2009 |url=http://minnesotaindependent.com/33294/on-climate-science-bachmann-accused-of-making-things-up-on-the-house-floor |accessdate=July 5, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100630061044/http://minnesotaindependent.com/33294/on-climate-science-bachmann-accused-of-making-things-up-on-the-house-floor |archivedate=June 30, 2010 }} In March 2008 Bachmann introduced H.R. 849, the [[U.S. Lighting Energy Policy#Light Bulb Freedom of Choice Act|Light Bulb Freedom of Choice Act]]. The bill would have repealed two sections of the [[Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007]] signed into law by [[George W. Bush]]. The 2007 Energy Act mandates energy efficiency and labeling standards for [[Incandescent light bulb|incandescent]] and [[Fluorescent light bulb|fluorescent bulbs]]. Bachmann's bill would have required the [[Government Accountability Office]] to show that a change to fluorescent bulbs would have "clear economic, health and environmental benefits" before enforcing lighting efficiency regulations. The bill would have allowed these standards to remain in place if the comptroller general found they would lead to consumer savings, reduce carbon-dioxide emissions and pose no health risks to consumers (such as risks posed by the presence of mercury in fluorescent bulbs). The bill languished in the House and became inactive at the end of the 110th Congress. Bachmann reintroduced the bill in March 2011.{{cite web|last=Kasperowicz |first=Pete |url=http://thehill.com/blogs/floor-action/house/147007-bachmann-let-there-be-incandescent-light |title=Bachmann: Let there be (incandescent) light – The Hill's Floor Action |publisher=Thehill.com |date=March 2, 2011 |accessdate=December 23, 2011}}{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-503544_162-20038472-503544.html |title=Bachmann to Democrats: Don't tell Americans what light bulbs to buy – Political Hotsheet |publisher=CBS News |date= March 2, 2011|accessdate=December 23, 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130211125743/http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-503544_162-20038472-503544.html|archivedate=February 11, 2013 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.meetthe112th.com/latest-news/bachmann-reintroduces-light-bulb-freedom-of-choice-act/ |title=Bachmann reintroduces Light Bulb Freedom of Choice Act |publisher=Meet the 112th |date=March 3, 2011 |accessdate=December 23, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120426023437/http://www.meetthe112th.com/latest-news/bachmann-reintroduces-light-bulb-freedom-of-choice-act/ |archivedate=April 26, 2012 }} ====Lawsuit reform==== On June 3, 2008, President Bush signed the Credit and Debit Card Receipt Clarification Act (H.R. 4008) into law. The bipartisan bill, which Bachmann cosponsored with Congressman [[Tim Mahoney]] (D-[[Florida|Fla.]]), removes statutory damages for violations of a 2003 federal law prohibiting merchants from printing consumers' credit card numbers and expiration dates on sales receipts, in order to end [[class-action]] lawsuits aimed at businesses that violated the law.{{cite news|title=Bachmann helps simplify credit card math|work=Star Tribune|location=Minneapolis|first=Kevin|last=Diaz|date=June 3, 2008|url=http://politicalblogs.startribune.com/bigquestionblog/?p=1016|accessdate=January 23, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090817094406/http://politicalblogs.startribune.com/bigquestionblog/?p=1016|archivedate=August 17, 2009|df=mdy-all}} ====Financial sector==== Bachmann opposed both versions of the [[Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008|Wall Street bailout bill]] for America's financial sector. She voted against the first proposed $700 billion bailout of financial institutions, which failed to pass, 205–228. She also advocated breaking up [[Fannie Mae]] and [[Freddie Mac]] and barring executives from excessive compensation or [[golden parachute]]s, and advocated a plan that would suspend [[mark-to-market]] accounting rules and suspend the [[capital gains tax]].{{cite web| title = Bachmann Statement on the Failure of the Bailout Bill| publisher=The Office of Rep. Michele Bachmann|date=September 29, 2008| url = http://bachmann.house.gov/News/DocumentSingle.aspx?DocumentID=104080| accessdate =January 23, 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081004025837/http://bachmann.house.gov/News/DocumentSingle.aspx?DocumentID=104080|archivedate=October 4, 2008 }} ====Auto industry==== {{See also|Effects of the 2008–10 automotive industry crisis on the United States}} The American auto companies approached Congress to ask for roughly $15 billion in loans to keep them operational into 2009. Bachmann criticized that bill, fearing that the initial sum of money would be followed by subsequent ones without the companies making changes to revive their business. Bachmann supported an alternative rescue for the American auto companies and the rest of the auto industry that would have set benchmarks for reducing their debt and renegotiating labor deals and have set up the financial assistance as interim insurance instead of a taxpayer-financed bailout.{{cite web| title = Bachmann Opposes Auto Industry Bailout| publisher=The Office of Rep. Michele Bachmann|date=December 11, 2008| url = http://bachmann.house.gov/News/DocumentSingle.aspx?DocumentID=107489| accessdate =January 23, 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081212013334/http://bachmann.house.gov/News/DocumentSingle.aspx?DocumentID=107489|archivedate=December 12, 2008 }} ====Call for a media exposé of Barack Obama and members of Congress==== On October 17, 2008, Bachmann gave an interview on [[MSNBC]]'s ''[[Hardball with Chris Matthews]]'' in support of the presidential campaign of Senator [[John McCain]] that brought the Minnesota 6th Congressional District race national attention. During the interview she criticized [[Barack Obama]] for his association with [[Jeremiah Wright]] and [[Bill Ayers]], saying "... usually we associate with people who have similar ideas to us, and it seems that it calls into question what Barack Obama's true beliefs, and values, and thoughts are ... I am very concerned that he [Barack Obama] may have [[anti-American]] views." She noted the bombing campaign orchestrated by [[Bill Ayers]] before discussing his association with Obama, arguing that "Bill Ayers is not someone the average American wants to see their president have an association with."{{Cite AV media|publisher=msnbc.com|title=Interview with Rep. Michele Bachmann|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/21134540/vp/27243547#27243547|accessdate=October 22, 2008|date=October 17, 2008}} Matthews followed up by asking "But he [Obama] is a Senator from the state of Illinois; he's one of the members of Congress you suspect of being anti-American. How many people in the Congress of the United States do you think are anti-American? You've already suspected Barack Obama, is he alone or are there others?" Bachmann answered, "What I would say is that the news media should do a penetrating exposé and take a look ... I wish they would ... I wish the American media would take a great look at the views of the people in Congress and find out are they pro-America, or anti-America. I think people would love to see an exposé like that."{{cite web|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/27297028/ |title=Transcript for ''Hardball with Chris Matthews'', October 17, 2008 |publisher=msnbc.com|date=October 21, 2008 |accessdate=September 13, 2010}} The five Democratic members of Minnesota's congressional delegation – [[Tim Walz]], [[Betty McCollum]], [[Keith Ellison (politician)|Keith Ellison]], [[Collin Peterson]] and [[Jim Oberstar]] – issued a joint statement in which they questioned her ability to "work in a bipartisan way to put the interests of our country first in this time of crisis".Horrigan, Marie; Kapochunas, Rachel & Stanchak, Jesse (October 21, 2008). [https://web.archive.org/web/20081025071449/http://www.cqpolitics.com/wmspage.cfm?docid=news-000002977499 CQ "Politics' House Rating Changes Topped by Bachmann Blow-Up"] ''[[CQ Politics]]''. Retrieved February 18, 2011. Former Secretary of State [[Colin Powell]]{{cite news|title=Powell: Support for Obama doesn't mean Iraq war wrong|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2008/POLITICS/10/19/powell.transcript/?imw=Y&iref=mpstoryemail|publisher=CNN|date=October 19, 2008|accessdate=February 18, 2011}}{{cite news|title=Colin Powell Calls Bachmann's Comments 'nonsense{{'-}}|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2008/10/19/politics/politico/thecrypt/main4531191.shtml|date=October 19, 2008|accessdate=February 21, 2011|publisher=CBS News}} and former Minnesota Governor [[Arne Carlson]]{{cite news|title=Carlson endorses Obama, spurred by Bachmann remarks |url=http://www.startribune.com/politics/32973804.html |work=Star Tribune |location=Minneapolis |date=October 23, 2008 |accessdate=February 18, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100918052337/http://www.startribune.com/politics/32973804.html |archivedate=September 18, 2010 }} said her comments had influenced their decisions to endorse Obama for president. Bachmann brought up the interview before business leaders and Republicans during a campaign stop in [[St. Cloud, Minnesota]], on October 21, 2008. She stated that she never intended to question Obama's patriotism. "I made a misstatement. I said a comment that I would take back. I did not, nor do I, question Barack Obama's patriotism ... I did not say that Barack Obama is anti-American nor do I believe that Barack Obama is anti-American ... [But] I'm very concerned about Barack Obama's views. I don't believe that socialism is a good thing for America."{{cite news|title=Bachmann: 'I made a misstatement{{'-}}|url=http://www.startribune.com/politics/31812514.html?elr=KArksLckD8EQDUoaEyqyP4O:DW3ckUiD3aPc:_Yyc:aUnciatkEP7DhUsX|date=October 22, 2008|work=Star Tribune|location=Minneapolis|first=Pat|last=Doyle}} In March 2010, Bachmann said, "I said I had very serious concerns that Barack Obama had anti-American views—and now I look like Nostradamus" while speaking at a fund-raiser for the [[Susan B. Anthony List]].{{cite news|url=http://minnesotaindependent.com/56783/clark-fundraises-over-bachmanns-latest-anti-american-comments |title=Clark fundraises over Bachmann's latest 'Anti-American' comments |work=[[The Minnesota Independent]] |first=Andy |last=Birkey |date=October 22, 2008 |accessdate=September 13, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100908022741/http://minnesotaindependent.com/56783/clark-fundraises-over-bachmanns-latest-anti-american-comments |archivedate=September 8, 2010 }}{{cite news|url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0310/34989.html#ixzz0jDgzxi7j|date=March 25, 2010|title=Tim Pawlenty, Michele Bachmann headline anti-abortion fundraiser|first=Andy|last=Barr|work=[[Politico (newspaper)|Politico]]|accessdate=September 13, 2010}} A year later, in March 2011, Bachmann was asked on ''[[Meet the Press]]'' if she still believed that Obama held un-American views. She responded, "I believe that the actions of this government have—have been emblematic of ones that have not been based on true American values." Pressed for clarification, she said, "I've already answered that question before. I said I had very serious concerns about the president's views."[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/41906285/ns/meet_the_press-transcripts "Meet the Press transcript for March 6, 2011"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121113015547/http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/41906285/ns/meet_the_press-transcripts |date=November 13, 2012 }}, ''[[Meet the Press]]'', March 6, 2011. ===111th Congress=== {{Further|111th United States Congress}} [[File:Bachmann2010.jpg|left|thumb|Bachmann speaking in April 2010]] ====Global currency==== On March 26, 2009, following comments by China proposing adoption of a [[global reserve currency]], Bachmann introduced a resolution calling for a Constitutional amendment to bar the dollar from being replaced by a foreign currency. Current law prohibits foreign currency from being recognized in the U.S., but Bachmann expressed concerns relating to the president's power to make and interpret treaties.{{cite web|url=http://www.startribune.com/politics/state/41919847.html?page=1&c=y|title=Bachmann: No foreign currency|date=March 26, 2009|website=[[Star Tribune]]|accessdate=April 4, 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090819095026/http://www.startribune.com/politics/state/41919847.html?page=1&c=y|archivedate=August 19, 2009 }} Earlier that month, at a [[United States House Committee on Financial Services|Financial Services Committee]] hearing, Bachmann asked both Treasury Secretary [[Timothy Geithner]] and Federal Reserve Chairman [[Ben Bernanke]] whether they would reject calls for the U.S. to move away from the [[U.S. dollar]] and they replied that they would.{{cite web|url=http://briefingroom.thehill.com/2009/03/26/bachmann-bill-would-ban-global-currency/|title=Bachmann bill would ban global currency|date=March 26, 2009|publisher=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]|accessdate=May 3, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120713220825/http://briefingroom.thehill.com/2009/03/26/bachmann-bill-would-ban-global-currency/|archivedate=July 13, 2012|df=mdy-all}} ====2010 Census==== In a June 17, 2009, interview with ''[[The Washington Times]]'', Bachmann expressed concern that the questions on the [[2010 United States Census]] had become "very intricate, very personal" and that [[Association of Community Organizations for Reform Now|ACORN]], a community organizing group that had [[ACORN 2009 undercover videos controversy|come under fire]] the previous year, might be part of the [[Census Bureau]]'s door-to-door information collection efforts. She stated, "I know, for my family, the only question we will be answering is how many people are in our home. We won't be answering any information beyond that, because the Constitution doesn't require any information beyond that."Dinan, Stephen. [http://washingtontimes.com/news/2009/jun/17/exclusive-minn-lawmaker-fears-census-abuse/ "Exclusive: Minn. lawmaker vows not to complete Census"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161025183559/http://washingtontimes.com/news/2009/jun/17/exclusive-minn-lawmaker-fears-census-abuse/ |date=October 25, 2016 }}. ''Washington Times''. June 17, 2009. According to [[Politifact]], her statement was incorrect, as the Constitution does require citizens to complete the census.[http://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/statements/2009/jun/25/michele-bachmann/michelle-bachmann-claims-constitution-only-require/ Bachmann Earns Two More Pants on Fire.] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160507134436/http://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/statements/2009/jun/25/michele-bachmann/michelle-bachmann-claims-constitution-only-require/ |date=May 7, 2016 }} [[Politifact]]. June 25, 2009. Fellow Republican Representatives [[Patrick McHenry]] ([[North Carolina|N.C.]]), [[Lynn Westmoreland]] ([[Georgia (U.S. state)|Ga.]]) and [[John Mica]] ([[Fla.]]) – members of the [[United States House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform| Oversight and Government Reform]] [[United States House Oversight Subcommittee on Health Care, Benefits and Administrative Rules|Subcommittee on Information Policy, Census and National Archives]], which oversees the census – subsequently asked Bachmann not to boycott the population count.Kucinich, Jackie. [http://www.rollcall.com/news/36404-1.html "GOP House Trio Urges Bachmann to Reverse Boycott of Census"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160808102756/http://www.rollcall.com/news/36404-1.html |date=August 8, 2016 }}. ''[[Roll Call]]''. July 1, 2009. Along with Congressman [[Ted Poe]] ([[Texas|Tex.]]-02), Bachmann introduced the [[American Community Survey]] Act to limit the amount of personal information solicited by the U.S. Census Bureau.Pugmire, Tim. [http://minnesota.publicradio.org/collections/special/columns/polinaut/archive/2009/07/bachmann_propos.shtml Bachmann proposes limits on census information] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121015002159/http://minnesota.publicradio.org/collections/special/columns/polinaut/archive/2009/07/bachmann_propos.shtml |date=October 15, 2012 }}, ''[[Minnesota Public Radio]] News'', July 13, 2009. She reiterated her belief that the census asks too many personal questions.Rosenberg, Jeff. [https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20100327201204/http://mnpublius.com/2009/07/bachmann-doubles-down-on-census-craziness/ Bachmann doubles down on census craziness], ''MN Publius'', July 14, 2009. ====Cap and Trade legislation==== In March 2009, Bachmann was interviewed by the [[Northern Alliance Radio Network]] and promoted two forums she was hosting the next month in St. Cloud and Woodbury about Obama's proposed cap-and-trade tax policy to limit [[greenhouse gas]] emissions. Bachmann said she wanted Minnesotans "armed and dangerous on this issue of the energy tax because we need to fight back." Bachmann's office quickly clarified that she was speaking metaphorically, meaning "armed with knowledge." According to the ''[[Star Tribune]]'', her quote went viral across the Internet.{{cite news|url=http://www.startribune.com/politics/national/house/42478007.html?elr=KArksi8cyaiUo8cyaiUiD3aPc:_Yyc:aUU |title=The Messenger: Michele Bachmann: |work=Star Tribune |location=Minneapolis |date=April 9, 2009 |accessdate=April 10, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090818100042/http://www.startribune.com/politics/national/house/42478007.html?elr=KArksi8cyaiUo8cyaiUiD3aPc%3A_Yyc%3AaUU |archivedate=August 18, 2009 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://townhall.com/MediaPlayer/AudioPlayer.aspx?ContentGuid=2c59827d-9fb9-46da-9127-c839e6d5ac85 |title=Audio Player |publisher=Townhall.com |accessdate=September 13, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110527041322/http://townhall.com/mediaplayer/audioplayer.aspx?ContentGuid=2c59827d-9fb9-46da-9127-c839e6d5ac85 |archivedate=May 27, 2011 }} ====AmeriCorps==== In 2009, Bachmann became a critic of what she characterized as proposals for mandatory public service. Of the [[Edward M. Kennedy Serve America Act]], an expansion to [[AmeriCorps]] (a federal community service organization), she said in April: {{quote|It's under the guise of—quote—volunteerism. But it's not volunteers at all. It's ''paying'' people to do work on behalf of government ... I believe that there is a very strong chance that we will see that young people will be put into mandatory service. And the real concerns is that there are provisions for what I would call re-education camps for young people, where young people have to go and get trained in a philosophy that the government puts forward and then they have to go to work in some of these politically correct forums.{{cite news|url=http://minnesotaindependent.com/31237/bachmann-reedcuation-camps|title=Bachmann fears 'politically Emanuel#Controversy|distorted Emanuel's position on health care for the elderly and disabled.]] FactCheck.org stated, "We agree that Emanuel's meaning is being twisted."[http://www.factcheck.org/2009/08/deadly-doctor/ 'Deadly Doctor'?] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110827200537/http://www.factcheck.org/2009/08/deadly-doctor/ |date=August 27, 2011 }}, FactCheck.org When many doctors wanted to legalize [[euthanasia]] or [[physician-assisted suicide]], Emanuel opposed it.{{cite news | last = Pear | first = Robert | title = A hard-charging doctor on Obama's team |work=The New York Times | date = April 17, 2009 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2009/04/18/us/politics/18zeke.html}} On August 31, 2009, Bachmann spoke at an event in Colorado, saying of Democratic health care overhaul proposals that: {{quote|This cannot pass. What we have to do today is make a covenant, to slit our wrists, be blood brothers on this thing. This will not pass. We will do whatever it takes to make sure this doesn't pass.}} She outlined ideas for changing the health care system, including: "Erase the boundaries around every single state when it comes to health care", enabling consumers to purchase insurance across state lines; increase the use of [[health savings account]]s and allow everyone to "take full deductibility of all medical expenses", including insurance premiums; and [[tort reform]].{{cite web|url=http://coloradoindependent.com/36840/bachmann-slit-our-wrists-be-blood-brothers%E2%80%99-to-beat-health-care-reform |title=Bachmann: 'Slit our wrists, be blood brothers' to beat health care reform|first=Ernest|last=Luning|website=[[The Colorado Independent]]|date=August 31, 2009|accessdate=June 1, 2011}} Bachmann denounced the government-run health insurance [[public option]], calling it a "government takeover of health care" that would "squeeze out private health insurance".{{cite web|first=Pat| last=Doyle |url=http://www.startribune.com/templates/Print_This_Story?sid=52318332 |title=Health insurers fighting overhaul plan with cash |website=Star Tribune|location=Minneapolis |date=August 2, 2009 |accessdate=March 26, 2011}} ====Criticism of President Obama's visit to Asia==== In an interview with [[Anderson Cooper]] on November 3, 2010, when discussing cuts in government spending for Medicare and Social Security suggested by Congressman [[Paul Ryan (politician)|Paul Ryan]], Bachmann was asked what cuts in government spending she would make to reduce the deficit. She cited President Obama's then-upcoming visit to Asia as an example, saying it "is expected to cost the taxpayers $200 million a day. He's taking two thousand people with him. He'll be renting out over 870 rooms in India. And these are 5-star hotel rooms at the Taj Mahal Palace hotel. This is the kind of over-the-top spending, it's a very small example, Anderson." Bachmann was apparently referring to information in a story from the [[Press Trust of India]], attributed to "a top official of the Maharashtra Government privy to the arrangements for the high-profile visit", information that was also published in U.S.-based media such as [[The Drudge Report]]. In response to the news report's claim that 34 warships were accompanying the President, a Pentagon spokesman, Geoff Morrell, dismissed the account as "comical". The White House said that the press report figures were "wildly inflated" and had "no basis in reality".{{cite news| url=http://www.minnpost.com/derekwallbank/2010/11/05/23095/white_house_asian_trip_cost_bachmann_cited_has_no_basis_in_reality|title=White House: Asian trip cost Bachmann cited has 'no basis in reality{{'-}}|first=Derek |last=Wallbank|work=[[MinnPost.com]]|date= November 5, 2010}} While stating that they could not give the actual projected figures for security reasons, staffers maintained costs were in line with the official travel costs of previous presidents Bush and Clinton.{{cite news|title=Cost of Obama's Trip to India Angers Right|first=Brian |last=Montopoli|publisher=CBS News|date=November 4, 2010|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-503544_162-20021841-503544.html|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5u75kYyPZ?url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-503544_162-20021841-503544.html |dead-url=no|archivedate=November 9, 2010}} ===112th Congress=== ====Leadership run==== {{see also|List of Tea Party politicians}} [[File:Michele Bachmann by Gage Skidmore.jpg|right|thumb|Bachmann in February 2011]] After the [[United States House of Representatives elections, 2010|2010 elections]] and the announcement from Rep. [[Mike Pence]] that he was stepping away from his leadership position in the House, Bachmann announced on her Facebook page her intention to seek the position of [[House Republican Conference Chair]]. As Bachmann is the founder of the House's Tea Party Caucus, her announcement caused some to see the leadership election as "an early test of how GOP leaders will treat the antiestablishment movement's winners".{{cite news| url=http://www.bradenton.com/2010/11/04/2712987/bachmann-bid-for-gop-leadership.html|first=Laurie |last=Kellman|agency=Associated Press|title=Bachmann bid for GOP leadership gets cool reaction|date=November 4, 2010|archiveurl= https://www.webcitation.org/5u7CQOYif?url=http://www.bradenton.com/2010/11/04/2712987/bachmann-bid-for-gop-leadership.html |archivedate= November 9, 2010}} Many among the House's Republican leadership, including [[Eric Cantor]] and the retiring Mike Pence, were quick to endorse Rep. [[Jeb Hensarling]] for the position; [[Speaker of the United States House of Representatives|Speaker-to-be]] [[John Boehner]] remained neutral on the issue.{{cite news|date=November 3, 2010|title=Republicans Start Jockeying for Leadership Posts|newspaper=Wall Street Journal|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/washwire/2010/11/03/republicans-start-jockeying-for-leadership-posts/|first=Patrick |last=O'Connor|archiveurl= https://www.webcitation.org/5u7Cj1c7u?url=http://blogs.wsj.com/washwire/2010/11/03/republicans-start-jockeying-for-leadership-posts/ |archivedate= November 9, 2010}} Supporters of Bachmann's run include Reps. [[Steve King]], [[John Kline (politician)|John Kline]], [[Louie Gohmert]], [[Chip Cravaack]], [[Erik Paulsen]], as well as media personality and political commentator [[Glenn Beck]].{{cite news| url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/1110/44872.html|title=Michele Bachmann: I helped put gavel in Boehner's hands|first=Marin |last=Cogan|work=Politico|date=November 9, 2010|archiveurl= https://www.webcitation.org/5u7CqpRWi?url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/1110/44872.html |archivedate=November 9, 2010}} Listing her qualifications for the position Bachmann noted "I've done an effective job speaking out at a national and local level, motivating people with our message, calling attention to deficits in Obama's policy. I was instrumental in bringing tens of thousands of people to the U.S. capitol to rally against Obama care and to attend our press conference." She noted her work to keep the Tea Party within the GOP rather than having it become a third party thereby helping the party capture the House, stating "I have been able to bring a voice and motivate people to, in effect, put that gavel in John Boehner's hands, so that Republicans can lead going forward. …It's important that leadership represents the choice of the people coming into our caucus….I think I have motivated a high number of people to get involved in this cycle who may have sat it out and that have made a difference on a number of these races. I gave a large amount of money to NRCC and individual candidates and started Michele PAC, which raised $650,000 for members since July, so I was able to financially help about 50 people out." Bachmann's bid suffered a setback when she was passed over for the GOP's transition team on which Hensarling was placed.{{cite news|title= Michele Bachmann leadership bid looking shaky|first=Rachel |last=Weiner|url= http://voices.washingtonpost.com/44/2010/11/michele-bachmann-leadership-bi.html|date=November 8, 2010|newspaper=The Washington Post|archivedate=November 9, 2010|archiveurl= https://www.webcitation.org/5u7D0XXsu?url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/44/2010/11/michele-bachmann-leadership-bi.html }} Despite Bachmann's leading all other Representatives in fund raising, a Republican aide stated some "members are getting resentful of Bachmann, who they say is making the argument that you're not really a Tea Party supporter unless you support her. That's gone through the formation of the Tea Party Caucus and the formation of this candidacy of hers. It's just not so." Sarah Palin, with whom Bachmann had campaigned earlier in the year, declined to endorse her leadership bid, while other Tea Party favorites Reps Adam Kinzinger and Tim Scott were placed on the transition team. According to some senior House staff members, the party leadership was concerned about some of Bachmann's high profile faux pas, the high rate of turnover among her staff, and how willing she would be to advance the party's messaging rather than her own.Ashley Parker [https://www.nytimes.com/2010/11/20/us/politics/20bachmann.html Michele Bachmann's Popularity Puts G.O.P. on the Spot] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160807082849/http://www.nytimes.com/2010/11/20/us/politics/20bachmann.html |date=August 7, 2016 }} ''[[The New York Times]]'' November 20, 2010 On November 10, Bachmann released a statement ending her campaign for Conference Chair and giving her "enthusiastic" support to Hensarling.{{cite web|title=A Campaign Ends |url=http://www.nationalreview.com/corner/253059/campaign-ends-nro-staff# |date=November 10, 2010 |website=The National Review Online |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101111165731/http://www.nationalreview.com/corner/253059/campaign-ends-nro-staff |dead-url=no |archivedate=November 11, 2010 |df= }} ====Committee assignment==== Bachmann was selected by House Speaker John Boehner for a position "on the [[United States House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence|House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence]], giving her a new role as overseer of the [[Central Intelligence Agency]], the [[National Security Agency]] and the rest of the U.S. intelligence community."{{cite news|title=Rep. Bachmann lands post on intelligence committee|author=Michael Isikoff|publisher=NBC News|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/40946997/ns/politics-capitol_hill|date=January 6, 2011}} Bachmann, who had "not served on any committee that deals with foreign policy issues" requested the position, "a move that has fueled speculation that she may be planning to carry the Tea Party banner into the GOP presidential primaries." ====Repeal of Dodd-Frank reform==== Soon after being sworn into her third term, Bachmann introduced legislation to repeal the [[Dodd–Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act|Dodd-Frank financial reform law]]. She stated, "I'm pleased to offer a full repeal of the job-killing Dodd-Frank financial regulatory bill. Dodd-Frank grossly expanded the federal government beyond its jurisdictional boundaries. It gave Washington bureaucrats the power to interpret and enforce the legislation with little oversight. Real financial regulatory reform must deal with these lenders who were a leading cause of our economic recession. True reform must also end the bailout mind-set that was perpetuated by the last Congress." She also took issue with the law for not addressing the liabilities of the tax-payer funded Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.{{cite news|last=Mattingly|first=Phil|title=Tea Party Caucus Founder Bachmann Pushes Measure to Repeal Dodd-Frank Law|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-06/tea-party-caucus-founder-bachmann-pushes-measure-to-repeal-dodd-frank-law.html|publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=January 7, 2011|date=January 6, 2011}} Bachmann's bill was endorsed by conservative groups such as the [[Club for Growth]] and [[Americans for Prosperity]]. It gained four other Republican co-sponsors, including Rep. [[Darrell Issa]], who became the new chairman of the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee at the start of the 112th Congress.{{cite web|title=GOP's Bachmann seeks to repeal Dodd-Frank…completely|date=Jan 6, 2011|url=http://blogs.marketwatch.com/election/2011/01/06/gops-bachmann-seeks-to-repeal-dodd-frankcompletely/|publisher=MarketWatch}} Bachmann's call for total repeal was seen as more drastic than the approach advocated by her fellow Republican [[Spencer Bachus]] who became the House Financial Services Committee Chairman with the change of majority in the House. Bachus "plans to provide 'vigorous' oversight of regulators efforts to reform banking and housing ... reform Fannie and Freddie", and "dismantle pieces of [the] Dodd-Frank Act that he believes 'unnecessarily punish small businesses and community banks.'" In response to Bachmann's legislation Rep [[Barney Frank]] stated, "Michele Bachmann, the Club for Growth, and others in the right-wing coalition have now made their agenda for the financial sector very clear: they yearn to return to the thrilling days of yesteryear, so the loan arrangers can ride again—untrammeled by any rules restraining irresponsibility, excess, deception, and most of all, infinite leverage." The chances of Bachmann's legislation passing were viewed as unlikely, the ''[[Financial Times]]'' wrote that "Like the Republican move to repeal healthcare reform, Ms Bachmann's bill could be passed by the House of Representatives but be blocked by the Senate or White House."{{cite web|title=Frank set for fight to defend regulatory overhaul|author=Tom Braithwaite|date=January 6, 2011|website=The Financial Times|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/370e0ec6-19e0-11e0-b921-00144feab49a.html#axzz1AIe4kCgf}} ====State of the Union response==== Bachmann responded to President Obama's 2011 State of the Union speech for the Tea Party Express website; this speech was broadcast live by [[CNN]]. She insisted that her response was not intended to counter the official Republican party response by Rep. [[Paul Ryan (politician)|Paul Ryan]] of Wisconsin. When asked if the speech was an indication of competition with Ryan and Speaker Boehner's leadership team, Bachmann dismissed such a view as "a fiction of the media", she had alerted Ryan and the leadership team that her response might go national and no objections were raised.{{cite news|title=Bachmann's State of the Union response raises her profile|agency=Associated Press|date=January 27, 2011|url=http://www.sctimes.com/article/20110127/NEWS01/101270036/Bachmann-s-State-of-the-Union-response-raises-her-profile}}{{dead link|date=December 2015}} ====Health care==== Bachmann has characterized the [[Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act]] as "ObamaCare", and has continually called for its repeal.{{cite news|url=http://www.cnsnews.com/news/article/rep-michele-bachmann-house-republicans-s |title=Rep. Michele Bachmann: House Republicans Should 'Fully Defund Obamacare' Under Congress' 'Power of the Purse' |date=January 7, 2011 |author=Nicholas Ballasy |publisher=CNSNews.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110116051332/http://cnsnews.com/news/article/rep-michele-bachmann-house-republicans-s |archivedate=January 16, 2011 }} She recalled to reporters that she called for debate to repeal the act "the morning after Obamacare passed". Joining with Rep. [[Steve King]] she introduced "the Bachmann-King repeal of health care bill" stating that it "is our intent in our heart to make sure that Obamacare is completely repealed." In light of a Democratic held Senate and Presidency that oppose repeal, Bachmann called on the Republican held House of Representatives to not provide any funds for the implementation of the act "But until we can see that [repeal] happen, we want to fully defund this bill so that, like, it would be akin to a helium balloon that gets no helium inside so that it can't take off the ground, and that's what we're planning to do. I'm very, very grateful for nothing else; having a majority in the House of Representatives so that we have the ability of the power of the purse to not fund Obamacare, and this is exactly the right way to go." On March 4, 2011, Bachmann (who was one of the six House Republicans to vote against the continuing resolution) expressed her unhappiness with the move that gave a two-week reprieve to the fear of government shutdown, stating "I am vowing to vote 'no' on future Continuing Resolutions to fund the government unless there is specific language included to defund Obamacare and rescind the funding that has already been appropriated. Defunding Obamacare, along with defunding Planned Parenthood, must be non-negotiable planks in our budget negotiations."{{cite news|title=Bachmann to vote against any funding bill that does not defund health-care law| url=http://dailycaller.com/2011/03/04/bachmann-to-vote-against-any-funding-bill-that-does-not-defund-health-care-law/#ixzz1G9eFDuVa |first=Chris | last=Moody|publisher=The Daily Caller|date=March 4, 2011}}{{cite news|title=Bachmann joins Tea Party supporters in plan to defund health care law|first=Derek| last= Wallbank|date=March 3, 2011| url=http://www.minnpost.com/derekwallbank/2011/03/03/26275/bachmann_joins_tea_party_supporters_in_plan_to_defund_health_care_law}} In an appearance on ''[[Meet the Press]]'' on March 6, 2011, and during a March 7, 2011, interview with [[Sean Hannity]], Bachmann declared that the Obama administration and the Congressional Democrats had hidden $105 billion in spending in the overhaul of the American Health Care System. She portrayed the Democratic leadership as timing the release of the bill's text to avoid detection of the spending "We didn't get the bill until a literally couple of hours before we were supposed to vote on it."{{cite news|title=GOP Lawmakers Target $105B in Spending Found in Health Care Law|date=March 8, 2011|publisher=Fox News|url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2011/03/08/gop-lawmakers-target-105b-spending-health-care-law/}} She also stated the spending was split up within different portions of the bill to mask its total cost. Bachmann was alerted of the situation by the conservative Heritage Foundation which read the tallies of the Congressional Research Service and Congressional Budget Office. Reports listed a partial breakdown of the costs which include "about $40 billion would go to the Children's Health Insurance Program, $15 billion would go to Medicare and Medicaid innovation programs, and $9.5 billion would go to the Community Health Centers Fund." As the funds are designated mandatory spending (they are not controlled by the annual appropriations acts), the funds would remain even if the move to defund the reform law succeeded. Bachmann stated that $16 billion of the money gives Health and Human Services Secretary [[Kathleen Sebelius]] a "slush fund ... [to do] whatever she wants with this money." She called on the bills supporters to return the money, "I think this deception that the president and [former House Speaker Nancy] Pelosi and [Senate Majority Leader Harry] Reid put forward with appropriating over $105 billion needs to be given back to the people."{{cite news|title=Bachmann accuses White House of hiding billions in health bill |author=Jeremy Herb |newspaper=Star Tribune |date=March 7, 2011 |url=http://www.startribune.com/politics/national/117500223.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110310152110/http://www.startribune.com/politics/national/117500223.html |archivedate=March 10, 2011 }} When asked during the Meet the Press interview if she would take back her previous comments that Obama "may have anti-American views" and that his administration had "embraced something called gangster government", Bachmann backed her statements, saying "I do believe that actions that have been taken by this White House—I don't take back my statements on gangster government. I think that there have been actions taken by the government that are corrupt ... I said I have very serious concerns about the president's views, and I think the president's actions in the last two years speak for themselves." In response to Bachmann's charges Chief Deputy Democratic Whip Rep. [[Jan Schakowsky]], who serves on the House health subcommittee, pointed out that the report Bachmann refers to is an update of a report that came out in October 2010 and that the costs were spelled out in both the bill and the Congressional Budget Office's estimate of its cost, "Michele Bachmann obviously didn't read the bill, because there was absolutely nothing hidden in that legislation." Schakowsky held that the costs were not kept secret, citing the $40 billion for the Children's Health Insurance Program as an example "There was a robust debate about whether or not that should be included, etc. So this idea of somehow, now at the last minute, there was a secret addition to some kind of funding ... is absolute nonsense."{{cite news|title=Was $105 billion Really 'Hidden' In The Health Law?|first=Julie | last=Rovner| publisher=National Public Radio |url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/health/2011/03/09/134398471/was-105-billion-really-hidden-in-the-health-law?ps=sh_sthdl}} In a September 2011 Republican presidential debate in Tampa, FL, Bachmann criticized [[Rick Perry]] for his support for the [[Human papilloma virus|humanpapilloma virus]] (HPV) vaccine and his support for mandating the HPV vaccine for all sixth-grade Texas girls.{{cite news|last1=Weiner|first1=Rachel|title=Bachmann claims HPV vaccine might cause 'mental retardation'|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/the-fix/post/michele-bachmann-continues-perry-attack-claims-hpv-vaccine-might-cause-mental-retardation/2011/09/13/gIQAbJBcPK_blog.html|accessdate=April 10, 2015|work=The Washington Post|date=September 13, 2011}} The [[American Academy of Pediatrics]], [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]], [[American Academy of Family Physicians]], [[American Congress of Obstetricians and Gynecologists|American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists]], [[Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices]] and other medical organizations worldwide are in favor of immunizing girls and boys against HPV.{{cite news|last1=Grady|first1=Denise|title=Remark on HPV vaccine could ripple for years|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/09/20/health/20hpv.html?_r=0|accessdate=April 10, 2015|work=The New York Times|date=September 19, 2011}}{{cite news|last1=Steenhuysen|first1=Julie|title=Analysis: Bachmann vaccine comments toxic, doctors say|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/09/15/us-cancer-hpv-idUSTRE78E5YM20110915|accessdate=April 10, 2015|work=Reuters|date=September 15, 2011}} HPV can cause lesions and genital warts, and has been linked to cervical cancer as well as genital and oral cancers in people of any gender.{{cite news|last1=Gann|first1=Carrie|title=Michele Bachmann's HPV Vaccine Safety and 'Retardation' Comments Misleading, Doctors Say|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Health/Wellness/michele-bachmanns-hpv-vaccine-safety-retardation-comments-misleading/story?id=14516625|accessdate=April 10, 2015|work=ABC News|date=September 14, 2011}} Because the vaccine is effective only if given before the onset of sexual activity and subsequent exposure to the virus, medical groups recommend the three dose vaccine be given to 11- and 12-year-olds.{{cite news|last1=Hensley|first1=Scott|title=Pediatricians fact-check Bachmann's bashing of HPV vaccine|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Health/Wellness/michele-bachmanns-hpv-vaccine-safety-retardation-comments-misleading/story?id=14516625|accessdate=April 10, 2015|work=NPR|date=September 13, 2011}} Bachmann, during the debate and in interviews following the event, accused Perry of "crony capitalism" (because Perry's former chief of staff was chief lobbyist for a drug company manufacturing the vaccine), and claimed that the HPV vaccine was dangerous and caused mental retardation. She repeatedly referred to an anecdotal account from a mother of a girl who been immunized for HPV. "She told me that her little daughter took that vaccine, that injection, and she suffered mental retardation thereafter," Bachmann said. "There is no second chance for these little girls if there is any dangerous consequences to their bodies." Shortly after Bachmann's statements at the debate, the American Academy of Pediatrics released a statement: "The American Academy of Pediatrics would like to correct false statements made in the Republican presidential campaign that HPV vaccine is dangerous and can cause mental retardation. There is absolutely no scientific validity to this statement. Since the vaccine has been introduced, more than 35 million doses have been administered, and it has an excellent safety record." Fewer than one percent of those receiving the vaccine reported neurological side effects or, in rare cases, severe allergic reactions, none linked to changes in cognitive ability. Bachmann later acknowledged that she was not a doctor or a scientist. ====Letter on Muslim Brotherhood influence==== In June–July 2012, Bachmann and several other Republican legislatorsRep. Trent Franks, Texas Rep. Louie Gohmert, Florida Rep. Tom Rooney and Georgia Rep. Lynn Westmoreland [https://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2012/07/19/michele-bachmann-sticks-to-accusations-about-muslim-brotherhood Michele Bachmann Sticks To Accusations About Muslim Brotherhood] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161110071511/http://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2012/07/19/michele-bachmann-sticks-to-accusations-about-muslim-brotherhood |date=November 10, 2016 }} sent a series of letters to oversight agencies at five federal departments citing "serious security concerns" about what Bachmann has called a "deep penetration in the halls of our United States government" by the [[Muslim Brotherhood]].
